title: Baumbach's chronicle of escalating stakes in divorce war hits the mark!
review:
With Marriage Story, Noah Baumbach has cemented his reputation as one of the more sophisticated screenwriters in Hollywood today. His film however should be more appropriately titled, "Divorce Story," as his narrative is basically a distillation of the unraveling of a marriage. The couple in question is Nicole and Charlie, played with subtlety by Scarlett Johansson and Adam Driver. Their battle is over where their 8 year-old son Henry should be growing up-east or west coast, as it turns out.

The film begins on a deliciously ironic note. We're treated to sets of voice overs from each of the principals, extolling the virtues of each others' personalities. On the surface it appears the marriage has not unraveled at all-yet.

But as the camera pulls back, Nicole and Charlie are in a marriage counselor's office, reading off their assignments from the counselor-to praise each other, in an attempt to find common ground. But it's also immediately made clear that each party feels the marriage is irretrievably lost, despite the positive pronouncements in these essays they've been reading, in the opening sequence.

We soon learn that Nicole, a talented actress, has supported Charlie, an up and coming director who runs his own theater company.in New York City. When Nicole has the opportunity to work on a pilot for a new TV show in Los Angeles, Charlie is under the impression that she and Henry will be returning to New York, after the TV opportunity wraps up-soon he discovers his assumption was incorrect (to put it mildly).

Baumbach's focus is not primarily on the warring couple and their disagreement-that no doubt would not work for an entire movie. He draws the battle lines clearly, however: Nicole wants Charlie to recognize her quest for independence-and she ultimately intends to remain in LA with their child, where she has the opportunity to flower. Charlie can't countenance her demand, as his burgeoning career is wrapped up in everything New York City.

It's how Baumbach chronicles the growing animus between them and the escalating conflict which proves so successful--coupled with how the deteriorating conflict proceeds in gripping increments, At first, the couple has agreed that they'll work the divorce out amicably-without attorneys present.

All bets are off however when Nicole is introduced to Nora (a deliriously fine Laura Dern), as the ball-busting divorce attorney, who's an expert at representing female clients. Charlie, still hesitant about enlisting an attorney, briefly flirts with hiring Jay (a thoroughly believable Ray Liotta), the attack-dog attorney who charges over $900 per hour. Soon after learning from Nora he's in jeopardy of losing custody of Henry and most of his earnings, Charlie finally conscripts Bert Spitz (Alan Alda), who urges him to cut his losses and allow Nicole to keep Henry in LA.

The stakes are exacerbated when Charlie drops Spitz and takes on Jay, who, in one of the best scenes in the film, duels with Nora in court, over Henry's fate. The judge ends up appointing an evaluator who will observe both parties in their interactions with Henry.

The family court evaluation ends up in disaster for Charlie, who ends up cutting himself (and bleeding profusely) with his small pocketknife which he carries around habitually on a key chain (it doesn't help that the female evaluator is completely unemotional). This probably leads to Charlie throwing in the towel at film's end and agreeing to Nicole's demand to keep their child on the west coast.

We can only conclude that Baumbach has done a bravura job in researching the vagaries of the divorce system-his superb characterizations of the attorneys involved are what ultimately give the film its compelling impetus.

Marriage Story is also a character study-not only the chronicle of Nicole's quest for independence but Charlie finally realizing that his demand to have Nicole and Henry return to NYC was tied to narcissistic careerism (Charlie eventually ends up in LA anyway, working as a university lecturer).

Baumbach also insightfully presents Nicole and Charlie's conflict as not entirely hateful. Even in Charlie's worst moment, when he has a meltdown in which he expresses his unbridled hatred for Nicole-there are still tender moments between them (as Charlie falls to his knees sobbing, Nicole cradles his head in her arms).

Baumbach's direction is so good due to his all-star cast. Some of the scenes could have moved a little quicker and one wonders why he inserted such a self-indulgent scene where he has Driver sing that entire Sondheim song from Company at the nightclub.. But these are minor peccadillos, as Marriage Story turns out to be one of the top films of 2019, certainly worthy of a best picture Oscar nomination, at the very least.

review:
Nothing new or particularly insightful here. Well off intelligent people act inexplicably stupid. Inexplicable because the characters are pretty much superficial stereotypes. Really don't get professional critics anymore.

title: this really broke my heart
review: Adam Driver literally deserved an Oscar for the singing "being alive" scene. Coz he is so alone in that 3 minutes and he did his best to being alive. His love for his son is so different from Nicole's. And he just didn't want the same tragedy happened in his childhood happening to his son. I totally understand the reason why Nicole and Adam divorcing. all i ever wanted was love. its such an excellent movie and i cry every time i watched this.

title: Our generation's Casablanca?
review:
Sadly, and as puke-y and trite as it sounds, will this film be looked back upon as our generation's Casablanca? It is kind of a Love Story for today. So many people get divorced. So many people can relate to the bi-coastal life question: one spouse gets a great opportunity in LA or Silicon Valley; do they uproot and move? Another couple struggles with jobs that require regular trips to DC or Boston - do they need to live apart? What will that do to the marriage? What kind of resentment would turning down these opportunities create? It brings out all of these questions and many others...albeit for a thin slice of humanity; the story is pretty limited to the lives of rich white people. And it does reek of the obnoxious "writers writing about writers" phenomenon we see so often in Hollywood.

Both Johansen and Driver are awesome. The director being a man means the film skews a tad bit more in favor of the man and makes you more sympathetic to him. (The fact that he cheated - she did not - is really glossed over).

Despite the movie being about divorce, there is so much love here. Between the parents, and between each parent and their child.

Also, there is a reason people say they hate lawyers. Is this the system we are stuck with?

title: Ok
review: People are so used to watching rubbish these days that when something mediocre comes along they think it's great. The truth is the acting wasn't brilliant. The scene where the couple argue, and he puts a hole in the wall, felt really forced. It even made me cringe. Apart from that it was passable.

title: Marriage story
review: I went in with I expectations for this movie as it has been highly praised by people from movie critics to everybody and even though it was a good movie there are some problems I had the acting was superb and excellent the directing was good I enjoyed the movie a lot.... now the bad stuff the music was awful and I didn't like it the music took me out of the movie it was composed by Randy Newman that's probably why it sounds like a Pixar movie some scenes were a bit corny and I diddint like because they were pointless and unnecessary but overall a great film didint expect this to be my thing but I liked it recommend this film a bit overrated but enjoyable

title: One of best watch of the year!
review:
Marriage story is a rooted, anti-melodramatic tale of a complicated divorce. And, it's also a MASTERPIECE !!! There's one particular scene involving the two leads in a room having a heated argument, that arrested me physically and melted me emotionally both at the same time. The argument scene is on par or in some ways even better than another similar favorite scene of mine from the Linklater movie 'Before Midnight'. It's one of the most well acted film of recent times. There are moments in the film that could be boring if not for the sheer presence of Adam driver and Scarlett Johansson. At no point are they acting, they're living the situation and that translates well into the audience. I wouldn't mind if both of the actors get a nod from the academy.

The film has lengthy but limited number of scene. Every scene takes time to build up, they're driven by life-like conversation, so it takes time to arrive at the point. But when it arrives, it hits hard, cheers to the time taken to build it up.

There's a lesson to be learned for up and coming writers, who are taught that you should enter the scene very late and exit as early as possible - there's a great reward for being patient.

title: Impactful realism (with no happy end?). It felt so true!
review:
I really admire the acting here, it felt so real and true to actual life. There is no classic 'happy end' to this, you get to see 2 sides of the medal. You can understand him and her... one thing I did not like that much: the film was still made to sympathize with - him. Often we stay in his perspective, follow him as he takes phonecalls from her et cetera. ... yet the film 'acts' like it shows both personalities and motives equally. To me it would have felt more real if both sides where shown equally.

Yet, the beginning of the movie was one of the best parts, the love letters felt - real. All the little things that makes a partner great were named... even if the main characters could not see them anymore at this given time. I know that this part alone defeats the purpose of this film, but for me - that is what inspired me personally for my own life and relationships.

Well done (even though it was not my favorite genre).

title: Some great performances but...
review: I think most people know what this movie is about. It could be titled Divorce story just as well. Adam and Scarlett are great, but its a sad movie, and one I probably won't watch again. A very good supporting cast as well, and the characters certainly feel real.

title: Marriage Story
review:
Despite the proliferation of channels such as Hallmark and Lifetime. Good films that show a realistic portrayal of a breakdown in a marriage and the subsequent divorce are few and far between.

The Oscar winning Kramer vs Kramer was 40 years ago. The black comedy The War of the Roses was 30 years ago.

Based on director's Noah Baumbach's own experiences of getting divorced. Charlie (Adam Driver) is a New York theatre director. His wife Nicole (Scarlett Johansson) is an actress who has recently moved back to Los Angeles to make a television series and taken their son Henry with her.

Although the couple agreed to divorce amicably without involving lawyers. Nicole then hires a hotshot divorce lawyer in LA, Nora Fanshaw (Laura Dern) who tells Nicole thaty being LA based would be advantageous for Nicole. In turn Charlie lawyers up. First he goes to a veteran attorney Bert Spitz (Alan Alda) whose advice seems to vary a lot but at least he sees the need to come to an agreement. Charlie then goes for the more pumped up and expensive Jay Marotta (Ray Liotta) and both sides end up slinging mud at each other.

I suppose most of the male audience will sympathise with Charlie and would be more willing to see events from his point of view. He is an up and coming theatre director with a show moving to Broadway. Charlie is confused as to why Nicole has gone legalistic. He fears losing contact with his son, he realises the expense of getting divorced and that he will end up footing the bill.

Most of the female audience will sympathise with Nicole. She has fallen out of love with Charlie, she now feels held back and thinks she can do better in LA. She suspects Charlie might have had an affair.

I watched the movie with my wife and she certainly sided with Nicole.

Marriage Story is a mature and intelligent movie. It doesn't take sides. Despite Charlie's and Nicole's best intentions of an amicable separation. They then repeat the same mistakes which thousands of other divorcing couple do the world over.

There is some humour in this movie, at times it is sad and raw. I did find the film overlong and the early part of the movie was slow paced.

title: 90 Minute Build-Up to a Career Best Scene for Both Driver and Johansson
review:
An emotional drama about a divorce is not exactly the kind of plot I usually go for, but what immediately struck me about Marriage Story was the quintessential feeling Baumbach brings to all his films. He has an unparalleled talent in tapping into real life and writing dialogue that feels so incredibly natural and authentic that it makes it easy to forget you're watching a movie at all. We're immediately sucked into the life and relationship of Charlie and Nicole with a monologue each about they love about one another. This is probably the happiest and most uplifting the movie gets. As soon as we're dragged back to the marriage counselling, the bitterness starts to creep in and we're pushed down an ever-winding helter skelter. Once Nicole employs a ruthless lawyer to oversee the divorce, things between them get uglier than ever, and our preconceived notions of who they are and what they meant to each other degrades at a phenomenal speed.

Almost all of Baumbach's films revolve around the concept of communication, or more accurately miscommunication, and Marriage Story is no different. It's fundamentally about a couple who couldn't clearly communicate their wants and needs to one another, and continue to miscommunicate in their break-up. They use lawyers as mouthpieces, saying things and asking for things they don't actually want. They remain polite and nice to each other, holding back their feelings, and letting it build to silent resentment. This all starts from the beginning, with Nicole refusing to read her love letter out to Charlie, and later taking his notes on the chin and bursting into tears as soon as she turns the corner.

And this miscommunication builds and builds and builds in intensity until it has to explode, and it does so in full force right in front of the screen. The pivotal argument in Charlie's apartment single-handedly changed my opinion of this entire movie, and will be used from here on out as a display of how insanely talented both Adam Driver and Scarlett Johansson are in front of the camera. All the truths between them are laid bare in a verbally violent altercation of the ages, in a single long shot. And yet neither Driver nor Johansson stutter or fall into caricature. They deliver their lines with equal intensity both rage and misery, and it's hard not to feel for both of them and what they've been through together and individually. So intense is the scene that I actually had to take a deep breath afterwards to compose myself. It's so viscerally raw and emotional to watch that I felt drained and overwhelmed by the time it was over.

It goes without saying, but this film was a career best for both Driver and Johansson, each of them slipping into their roles so easily it felt like they were just playing themselves re-enacting difficult parts of their own lives. If I had to pick, Driver gave the best performance, if only because he was given more space to do so. By the movie's mid-point, we definitely spend more time with Charlie than we do Nicole, and Driver makes use of every second. The argument is definitely the high point, for both of them, but Johansson also gets her own monologue to Laura Dern's Nora which is just as emotionally stirring, while Driver gets a subdued but heavy rendition of 'Being Alive' from the musical 'Company', as well as a heartbreaking scene at the end when their son Henry finds the love letter Nicole wrote about him.

As for complaints, in the lead-up to the argument, the movie was starting to lose me. I wasn't bored or finding it slow or dull, nor did I find any of the filmmaking aspects bad or hard to watch. But I found myself just getting so irrationally angry at the whole situation. From a purely factual standpoint, Charlie was the b*stard of the relationship. He was controlling and selfish, and a cheater on top of that. And yet putting Charlie front and centre for much of the movie just made me feel sorry for him. He was blindsided by the divorce, blindsided by Nora's ruthlessness, and blindsided by the financial cost it would have on him, all set on him by Nicole. It becomes very telling how semi-autobiographical this movie is of Baumbach's own divorce, acknowledging he was the cheater, but framing the story in such a way it lays most of the sympathy on his surrogate character, and the hardships Charlie has to go through at Nicole's behest. Putting Nicole behind the scenes for this portion of the movie, and essentially cutting out her side, really made her come off as the resentful b*tch putting Charlie through hell. The fact the movie makes a point that the blame can be laid on both sides almost makes this facet worse. If Nicole had just communicated her problems and desires more clearly and accurately, Charlie wouldn't have had to upend his life against his will and lose almost everything he earned. But I mean, as complaints go, I get the impression this was somewhat intentional on Baumbach's behalf. This was the point. He wants it to seem unfair, he wants it messy and his characters to both look terrible, he wants you angry at the system and how easily exploited it is at one party's loss.

I have no hands-on experience with divorce, but I found way too much of it relatable. We saw our sons in Henry, and we saw each other in Charlie and Nicole, but if nothing else, this movie just strengthened our relationship, showing us how bad things can get if we don't communicate properly and compromise for one another. But it's not a movie I could watch again. It's a hard pill to swallow, and as electrifying as both Driver and Johansson are, it's not enough to endure all that rage and misery again. Currently I'm sitting on a solid 8/10, but that argument scene was so...so...intense that I'm going to give it a whole point to itself. I give Marriage Story a 9/10. I'd advise grabbing a box of tissues before you begin.

title: Beautiful
review:
How this whole movie turn out to be so beautiful is beyond my imagination. You take a sensitive and absurd topic like divorce and you create something so beautiful out of it is pure genius.
Acting is brilliant
Writing is brilliant
Direction is brilliant.
And the best part is how the movie keeps you indulge with the story. You want something to happen but you know that won't happen but still the director just shoots hope in every scene.

title: Serious and solid.
review:
Serious and solid performances from Driver & Johansson in this well directed film.
Having said that it maybe overly long with a tendency to meander. That and the fact I may not be this film's target audience.

title: A penetrating look at the spiraling effect of divorce American style
review:
Noah Baumbach's ("The Meyerowitz Stories") Marriage Story is a penetrating look at the spiraling effect of divorce American style on those involved, one that radiates compassion for its beleaguered characters Nicole (Scarlett Johansson, "Avengers: Endgame") and Charlie (Adam Driver, "BlacKkKlansman") as they struggle to maintain their dignity through a dehumanizing process. If love means never having to say you're sorry, you are probably not living on planet Earth, though I'm sure other places may have their compensations. For Nicole and Charlie, however, just saying "I'm sorry" will not even reach the tip of the iceberg.

Nicole is a native of Los Angeles who left a budding movie career on the West Coast to move to New York with their young son Henry (Azhy Robertson, "After the Wedding") to star in the productions of her husband Charlie, an acclaimed theater director. In his role as Charlie, Driver is consistently brilliant in his portrayal of a man on the brink of despair, desperately trying to hold his life together in the face of fast changing circumstances, while Johansson has that uncommon quality that makes you care deeply about her. We first meet the two through film montages in which they discuss each other's virtues and idiosyncrasies, love letters asserting the qualities that they find endearing.

Nicole loves that Charlie is organized and dresses without embarrassing her. Charlie loves the way Nicole cuts his hair and makes tea and leaves it around the house. Charlie talks about his wife's devotion to playing with their son and how patient she is. To Nicole (who refuses to read hers out loud), Charlie never gets upset about the little things and is really a talented director. Unfortunately, we soon find out that the tributes were only written at the request of a marriage mediator as part of the couple's plans for divorce. Nicole refuses the request to read it aloud, however, and leaves the room in a fit of temper. This becomes more understandable when we learn that she has decided to take Henry with her to L.A. to shoot a TV pilot and pursue her movie ambitions.

Complicating the situation is the fact that Charlie has just received a MacArthur Fellowship and has agreed to live in New York. Further muddying the water is Charlie's affair with a woman at his theater company. Although Charlie believes Nicole plans to move back to New York after the shoot, she has other ideas and the thought of having to travel back and forth on a 3,000 mile trip to see his son does not sit well with Charlie. It seems to be resolved, however, when during his visit to California, he ends up being served divorce papers by Nicole's sister Cassie (Merritt Wever, "Greenberg") in one of the funniest scenes in a film in which humor is sparse but always welcome.

What starts out as an amicable separation between two people who treat each other with respect turns into a circus, however, when high-priced, aggressive, and uncaring lawyers, Laura Dern ("Star Wars: The Last Jedi"), Ray Liotta ("The Son of No One") and Alan Alda ("Bridge of Spies") come into the picture and the weather forecast becomes cloudy with a likelihood of rain. Fighting a custody battle for Henry, Dern is exceptional as Nicole's lawyer Nora Fanshaw, an outwardly warm and caring person, but underneath a saber-toothed cat who delivers a crusading speech about the different expectations for a woman. Charlie's second lawyer after the amiable, but too laid back, Bert Spitz (Alda) is Jay (Liotta in his best role since 2012's "The Place Beyond the Pines").

Jay is up front about the financial cost ($950 an hour) as well as the emotional cost in turning resolvable differences into attack weapons to corner and belittle his adversary. With some personal experience in the matter, Baumbach does his best not to show preference for either aggrieved party, but depicts the divorce process to be one that is filled with gladiator-like combat that only serves to draw the contesting parties further apart. While it is obvious that the charming, self-absorbed Charlie should have shown more awareness of Nicole's needs for a career of her own, it is equally the case that his wife's ability to communicate her needs was inadequate.

If "love is a function of communication," Nicole and Charlie forgot it somewhere along the way. The film's emotional high point is the animated, accusatory conversation between husband and wife, perhaps better described as a shouting match. Though well-written, the verbal sparring becomes overwrought, though it mercifully ignores excessive use of the "F" and "S" words, so lazily prevalent in today's culture as a substitute for thoughtful dialogue and wit. While Marriage Story covers a lot of ground and is open to many interpretations, it all but stays away from any deep examination of the larger issues in a relationship such as commitment, responsibility, and communication, the cornerstones of any successful marriage.

Asked what the film is about, Baumbach says, "It's many things; it's about how love is not always enough." As author Werner Erhard put it, however, "The truth is that that's all there is. And if you take the barriers out of the way, if you take the pretenses out of the way, if you take those things that you didn't take responsibility for in your life out of the way, what you have left is love," and adds, "You don't have to be looking for love when it is where you come from."

title: Giving up after 29 minutes.
review: I thought this might be good, BUT, good grief, a film about a self obsessed actress who is no longer the centre of attention? Seriously?? A derisible, disgraceful film.

title: Severely overrated
review:
This movie is overrated.
There are hundreds movies like this one.
Nothing exciting,nothing new and just waisted couple of hours.
And I dont understand people, who said they cried watching this movie? Why?
Definitely not the best movie of year .

title: Pretentious as hell
review: This is the kind of film that a director makes to "show how intelligent and brilliant" is. Everything is so calculated that looks ridiculous and fake. The only element that deserves attention and recognition is Laura Dern's interpretation. Wanna enjoy a real gem? Watch Kramer vs Kramer: true cinema.

title: Good, not great. (Spoilers)
review: The acting and script were great, especially if you liked the EXPECTED outcome (females win everything with compassionate genius lawyer). Charlie was kind of a putz and his prime lawyer was a stereotypical divorce lawyer, whereas the female lawyer was perfect until she had to fight ( which of course she won). Still a great watch

title: Good movie about very rich white people
review: If you would like to see a good movie about very rich white people, you might like this. They are very entitled and privileged also, if that helps.

title: painful to watch
review: Why was this nominated?? This movie was genuinely annoying to watch. There was no plot really. Two people are going through a divorce. That was the whole story. There. No need to watch it now. On top of it, the loooooong drawn out scenes were so forced... there was just nothing there. All empty dialog. That one scene where they were fighting... just horrible. And then he cuts himself because clearly there wasn't enough drama so they tried to come up with just anything at all - the most random unrelated stuff - literally just absolutely anything at all that could possible add an ounce of drama to this movie because otherwise they knew people would just fall asleep in their seats. I mean... so pointless, and boring, and horrible. The acting of course is great but it just can't make up for the poor writing. I don't understand who greenlights those projects?? Who thought that this would be a good movie?! They surely must have known it would be bad after reading the script. I don't think anyone even read the script. They just heard that some big names were attached and that's all they cared about. Seriously... and on top of it - this was nominated for best picture? I mean... wow. Just wow. NOT OK!!!

title: Not Good Enough
review: Boring. Johannsson needs to return to some acting classes after all those superhero films. Poorly written dialogue which my two other sisters watching found way too boring and delivered in superficial, expositorily for most folks going through divorce. On many occasions this all seemed forced and without enough rehearsal. I found that after watching British and European TV and film productions, this just is at that level.

title: Boring
review:
Bad reproduction of the movie Kramer vs. Kramer,
Long and boring conversations,
Scarlett Johansson is shaking her head in a strange and annoying way,
Adam Driver is the only good thing in this movie and deserves to be nominated, but there are stronger competitors of the year.

title: Overrated
review: Acting was wonderful and touching and sad movie. But the plot was very thin and it felt like a real divorce case (which was the goal I guess). But it didn't have much of an entertaining value. It gets 5 from me because the acting was very good but the story told in the movie was just sad and boring in my opinion.

title: Depressing
review: Very depressing movie. Romance? Where? Just selfishness.

title: Too long and lacks real emotion
review:
This is an OK movie that would have been better if 30 minutes was cut out of it. The surreal musical interludes were bizzare and awful. The arm cutting incident seemed like a desperate attempt at humour. It wasn't funny.
Not sure why it was called Marriage Story as it's really the story of a divorce, LA style. A few good moments, mainly involving the lawyers, basically save it from being a total bore.

title: Why marriage is dying
review: This hit close to home. Acting was pretty good. No one should ever get married in today's society.

title: Mistaken identify
review:
If you want to watch a film about a painful divorce, then you should watch this.

Adam Driver is very good but the character of the wife is so awful that it made the movie very hard to get through.

I wish I hadn't wasted more than 2hrs watching this.

title: Overrated
review: Above average acting on it's own doesn't make a good movie. If the script is rubbish, there is no way anyone can turn it into something great.

title: I Saw it Coming
review: While I give credit to the writer/director (who some people have heard of, although I hadn't) for being able to create a film, what he created was... what? My wife and I watched it last night and, from the beginning, I could tell this was going to be syrupy, self-indulgent, molasses-slow movie that, I assume, drew from his background in theatre and film. The characters in the stock company, the neurotic sister who acted like a child, the child who acted like a brat, the mediator who plays a cartoon character, and the dialogue between the two lawyers that I could visualize being delivered at a table reading kept me at a distance. Then there was the loooooooooong monologue delivered by the lead actress that, as she shared it with her lawyer, seemed so artificial and contrived that I felt sorry for her that she had to read what I'd imagine the writer thought would be an epic presentation. Like the lawyers' dialogue, you could visualize the writer knocking it out and the actress trying to make it real. Instead, all you hear is a Hollywood actress reading a Hollywood director's lines and without the illusion of reality -- which carries all the way through the ten hours of this two-hour film -- it's difficult to get into it. How this got six Academy Award nominations is anyone's guess. Maybe it's an inside joke.

title: Just plain dull
review:
Very slice of life. But I don't recognize any of the life that's being sliced. And I am a theater person - who's been through a divorce. There are moments of poignancy, but the film swings between overblown sentimentality and being just plain dull.

The leads are dull, the script is dull, and although Ms. Dern and Mr. Alda know what they're doing, Julie Hagerty's over-the-top turn as the mother is like something out of a "Carol Burnett Show" sketch.

There's no new insight here about marriage, parenthood, or divorce that hasn't been done much more skillfully in "Kramer vs. Kramer," or in any given episode of "This is Us."

title: What did I miss?
review: Reading some of these reviews is honestly more entertaining than the movie itself was. I must have missed something.

title: A portrait of terrible people
review: Difficult to watch, I just wanted to smack the two main characters. Depicts the worst of the worst by people who claim to be good. Five stars for great acting but the story is dreadful and you couldn't pay me to watch it again.

title: Way overrated
review:
I can't believe the rating before my eyes, 8.3 !!!!! What has happened to the world ?

The fundamental problem I have with this movie is that I never felt the hatred between them, he supposedly wishes she is dead and yet seems genuinely happy every time he sees her , same goes to her , in one scene she gave warm smiles as if they were falling in love or sth , We see her cry but that is not enough, she is not angry, she is not depressed, she is not quite and she is definitely not in pain as we might have assume , given the events. I don't know about the couple of thousands who have seen the movie and applauded the "fight" scene and rated it 8.2 accordingly; but I have seen people getting divorced, especially mothers with small kids , it is horrible, heartbreaking, and sad This movie doesn't feel sad

title: Overrated and BORING
review: It seems like I watched an ordinary film with the ordinary divorce story. Nothing to be highly rated here and I don't know why does this film has high ratings. Better go and watch "WILDLIFE" (2018) for better understanding family problems.

title: BOO!
review: Whoever gives this a high rating is trash just like this movie, and has probably had a divorce if not more than one

title: Yak Yak Yak
review: Full of boring dialogue ,boring characters and a storyline that's rehashed again and again over the years. We turned it off after an hour.

title: Am I missing something?
review:
This is way overhyped and awfully overrated I was not fully convinced but in the end I decided it was maybe worth the watch and all I can say is that this is not a bad movie, I definetely didn't hate it but is not perfect at all

The acting is great 10/10 that is no lie, everyone is bringing it and it shows but a movie is not just great acting I get that this is trying to be a "real" view of a family life going through a divorce, and granted I am lucky to say I haven't had that experience but I felt it was a little bit pretencious or the message went way over my head because I don't agree with all the 10 stars reviews nor with the 1s I guess this is gonna be one of those where people are gonna be either lovers or haters

For me it's a 6 just a little over half A solid meh..

title: The movie is really good,, but I don't know what the fuss is all about !!
review:
Okay,, so the movie is really good,, probably one of the best Netflix had to offer this year but the "story" itself doesn't deserve that big fuss..

The plot is just an everyday story,, couples in love go though divorce, do everything to protect their kid ... so I wouldn't say it's an original , now .. why the 9 stars !!!

The 9 stars is for the phenomenal performance by the cast ,, especially Adam Driver !!!! My god he just appears so big for any project you put him in .. and man ,, his emotional side was so noticeable here ... bravo .. Scarlett also did great, and she connected so damn well with the emotional back and forth with Adam... and the whole crew was just a perfect blend.

Anyway, the movie is great .. Recommended.

title: Leaves you hoping there is a Marriage Story 2. One of the Years Best!
review:
I am not a big fan of either of the lead actors but both where fabulous in this trip through a painful legal divorce battle. The supporting cast from Liotta to Dern where perfect and I was trilled to see Julie Hagerty in a nice size role as her mother.
Anyone who has been through the process especially when a small child is involved can feel their pain while clearly understanding that they still love each other. Sometime Life's choices don't work out because both want things to go in different directions. The movie never rushes through important scenes and left me wishing there would be more to tell about this relationship in the future.

title: Modern-Day Ripoff of "Kramer vs. Kramer"
review: First of all, Adam Driver is excellent and rightfully deserves any and all awards directed his way ... That's the end of it - storyline is too familiar and particularly resembles "Kramer vs Kramer" but more from the adult-to-adult relationship instead of Kramer's father-to-son approach ... Scarlett Johansson is more sympathetic than Meryl Streep character but you still root for Driver's prevail in the divorce settlement ... Despite what you read about the movie's ending, it's not a happy and continues to represent how selfish and arrogant that divorce is.

title: Does it HAVE to BE This Way??
review:
Wouldn't it be nice if people just wrote down what they wanted, surpassed the idiot attorneys (who could not possibly care less if you were on fire, as long as they get their but and the bigger the better), and just went straight to court and be done with it?

Guess what USA? You CAN get a divorce without attorneys. If you genuinely love your kid (as a human being, not a possession or worse: a PAWN)...then do this divorce thing correctly. Put your money where your mouth is, save the bloody money for the kid you love so much and nix the attorneys. Sickening 'reality tv' cat fight muck.

If you mean it, you want an amicable divorce, you CAN do it without attorneys. Again: They do not have your best interests at heart, your kid means absolutely nothing to them...they only care about how much they can leech out of your horrible situation for themselves.

Haven't we all learned this yet?? Attorneys and Insurance Companies are the root of all evil. This movie proves half of that.

title: What's you expect from Noah Baumbach films!?
review: Masterpiece in everything acting and directing and writing It is a wonderful experience that I had.

title: Movies that make you cry
review:
Best of 2019
Top 200ish movies
I still need to think about it and maybe rate it higher. Adam Driver and Scarlett Jo gave best performances in their careers and Laura Dern was also amazing. The ending was heartbreaking and hell I'm only 19, I don't even know what being married feels like. I love how Noah Baumbach is telling the same story from two different perspectives and he isn't on anyone's side. I wasn't that invested into the story from the start but after 15 minutes I was pulled right into it. Also, Adam Driver is singing again!!! We need to put that man in the musical!

title: One Of The Best
review:
I debated whether or not to even write anything about Marriage Story. It has touched so many people, and I don't want to come at this disrespectfully, because, in my life, I have not experienced divorce. My wife and I have been married happily for 20 years. My parents are about to celebrate their 50th wedding anniversary. And both my maternal and paternal grandparents were married for nearly 70 years and nearly 50 years respectively. So I guess I feel like I'm trespassing here. But I love movies. And I loved this one. And there are many things that are done well in this film. so here I go. First I should say that I have not been a huge fan of Noah Baumbach in the past. It is not like I have anything against directors who concentrate on smaller stories that seem as if they are actually pulled from the pages of real life. In fact, I love independent cinema when it is done well. Alexander Payne, Kenneth Lonergan, and Wes Anderson (although Anderson's films are more surreal sometimes) are some of my favorite directors. Again I think this movie is done well. The screenplay is very good. The acting is phenomenal, worthy of the award nominations I am sure are going to come to fruition. And the direction always seems sure of itself (save for a few scenes that go on longer than they should). But it's more than that. However, before I expand on that let me address some of the things that may make people a little hesitant about seeing Story. It's depressing. There is no getting around that. in fact, there is a point in Story where the depressing part of the film becomes so overwhelming, that it actually begins to almost physically hurt. it's predictable and it knows it. Almost from frame one, everyone who I saw it with knew exactly where it was going. And like in real life, there is no real silver lining. But it's not hopeless. And here is why, if people are hesitant to see this movie, they should ignore those feelings of hesitation. The son. As far as hope is concerned, the son in this film is the most hopeful part of the this couple's existence. He is the glue that keeps the lives of the characters together, even when divorce rips them apart. And as far as it being depressing...well...that's life . But I can say that every depressing experience that I have ever been a part of, and although divorce has not affected me, I have still had my fair share depressing moments, there's always a ray of hope somewhere. The lives of these people have that ray of hope as well. And because of that, there is a feeling that they, in the long run, will be alright. Another reason to see this movie has to do with the supporting characters. From the attorneys, to the extended families, almost everyone has someone who lifts them up when everything comes crashing down. One of my favorite songs is called "Held," by Natalie Grant. In it, there is a line that I love. Grant clearly means it in a religious sense, but almost anyone can relate to it. It says,

This is what it means to be held, how it feels when the sacred is torn from your life and you survive. This is what it is to be loved and to know that the promise was when everything fell we'd be held

Everyone has someone who, when life comes crashing down, will hold them. When Story was over, l felt like that would be true for the two main characters in the story. No matter what...no matter where they end up, they will always have the people in their lives to count on. And I think that even includes each other.

title: Awful, Uninspiring, Boring faux Hipster drivel
review:
If ever there was a reason for #oscarssowhite to trend, this excrement is proof. I was not expecting Kramer v Kramer, but I thought an Academy Award nominee for best picture, with both acting leads and one supporting lead being nominated as well, could surpass a Lifetime Movie of the Week. I was sorely mistaken. This is a faux emotionally wrought story with very lame situations and awful comedic interludes. Many situations appear extremely contrived while the lawyer characters (all three...Ray, Dern, Alan Alda) are pure caricatures. The dialogue is really bad... "half of crazy is still crazy!". Laura Dern is a likable actress but was nonsensical as the cool, hip, jeans and heels wearing feminist femme fatale lawyer.

Zero chemistry between ScarJo and Driver. Awkward mostly. The big fight scene was absurd. The kid actor among the worst in history...Michelle in Full House circa 1992 did it better.

Why is this best picture worthy? Awful.

title: This had potential...
review:
Wow, this movie had so many possibilities to become a moving but relatable story. What a shame. I give it three stars due to the acting of Adam Driver. Although this wasn't his best performance, not even close, I do feel like he played a grounded role-a catalyst to the plot. However, the rest of the acting, in my opinion was simply atrocious. Scarlet Johansson had her moments within scenes where I felt she had shined but for the most part, I felt a disconnect to her character and never felt like her emotion successfully penetrated anyone. As for the rest of the cast, I was shocked at how corny and pretentious everyone was.

I don't know if this was caused from a faulty script or just poor acting entirely, but quite frankly, i was highly disappointed. The lawyer sought out by driver towards the beginning was the biggest cliche of the entire film. Tacky, rude, and extremely over the top. Don't even get me started on Julie Hagerty's performance.

What a let down for such a well selected cast. I found a more meaningful side story of a repaired marriage in Jon Favreau's Chef.

title: Raw & deeply real portrayal of love, divorce, & family.
review:
Raw & deeply real portrayal of love, divorce, & family. A timeless story with original execution.

📽Audience REACTIONS at its Canadian PREMIERE: 😄😄😄😄😄😂😄😄😄😄😄😄😄😄(14 laughing scenes) 😭(1 cry) 👏👏(2 applauses during film) 🏆TIFF Peoples Choice 1st Runner Up 🏆(strong Oscar potential for: Best Picture, Best Director, Best Actress - Scarlett Johansson, Best Actor - Adam Driver, Best Supporting Actress - Laura Dern, Best Original Screenplay, Best Film Editing)

Marriage Story (Noah Baumbach) is a raw and deeply real portrayal of love, divorce, and family. It is a combination of a love story, screwball comedy, musical, and procedural drama. While the blend of styles at a point comes across as forced, the film as a whole is a brilliant work, telling a story rather than following the genre troupes many films fall into. This is a simple story originally executed.

Extremely character driven, the cast play their roles perfectly. Scarlett Johansson and Adam Driver lead the balanced portrayal of a divorcing couple. This film will impact viewers differently depending on many factors, especially their life stage and past experiences with relationships, marriage, and divorce. The film is so well balanced that one viewer will relate more to one character while the person beside them may be more drawn to the other. Regardless of which lead you relate to more, you are bound to be shaken by the deeply emotional performances of both.

A nod to the cast would be incomplete without a special mention for Laura Dern and Ray Liotta whose characters come to life in significant scenes of their own. The director shared at TIFF that at many times during filming he felt like he was watching the actor's movie rather than his and this truly shines through in their collective performance. Out of the many films we saw in Toronto over two weeks, Marriage Story likely has the best odds for this year's Oscar wins.

title: Moving one to those who appreciate marriages
review: Wow well done in portraying the ugly side of a love story. Flawless performance from Driver and Johansson, my heart broke into pieces at the end. Very moving, very true marriage's issues that sometime neither one willing to sacrifice any further nor being flexible, then divorce is the way forward. Just wish it had a happy ending though bcoz Nicole still loves Charlie but Charlie was just simply too self absorbed too see he's hurting Nicole. I hate divorce lawyers to the core!

title: A MARRIAGE AT THE SEAMS...!
review: Noah Baumbach's (The Squid & the Whale/Greenberg) current Oscar bait, airing on Netflix, stars Adam Driver & Scarlet Johansson as a couple in the throes of divorce. He is a theater director in New York, she is an actress & California transplant, who had a hit film back in the day but now performs in a play her beau is mounting for the stage. Something has happened & we never get a definitive cause as to the genesis of their breakup but when civility starts to crumble (they're hoping to negotiate the divorce on their own for peace of mind & their young son) but when accusations & resentments begin to surface, lawyers are engaged (she has Laura Dern in her corner while he gets Alan Alda & Ray Liotta). What follows is a modern update of Kramer Vs. Kramer (Best Picture winner 40 years ago) in which words do strike blows (their final verbal brush-up is more potent & devastating than any cinematic gunfight witnessed in some time). Baumbach, as always is a master of character & situation, as he has always mined the humor found in the most debase of scenarios. Who knows if the director's real life break-up w/actress Jennifer Jason Leigh (she is a celebrated actress from the West Coast) inspired the proceedings here but one hopes a lot of the emotional carnage on display is pure supposition. Also starring Merritt Weaver (as ScarJo's sister), Julie Hagerty (nice to see her again, this time playing the mother who doesn't favor sides) & Wallace Shawn ("Inconceivable!") playing an actor in Driver's troupe.

title: Move over Kramer vs Kramer. This is the best portrayal of divorce.
review:
The second great film of 2019, after _the Irishman_ and both from Netflix.

The script is heart breaking, funny and the screenplay is as real as they come. The scenes where a normal argument escalates into serious conflicts are the ones that hit the hardest. the comic respite is often unexpected and witty.

Both Driver and Johannson would get the respective Oscar nominations for the roles of their lives.

It is a must watch for all lovers of great cinema. Can't be recommended highly enough.

title: Dissection of the Human Soul trough de lenses of marriage.
review: Marriage Story is a great example of pacing and emotional levity in film. I mean, there is so much that it's being said about Adam Driver's and Scarlet Johansson's performances, as they both deliver poignant and heart wrenching depictions of what is like to be a complex and often contradictory human being, it is nonetheless astonishing the virtuosso manner in wich Noah Baumbach picks the key moments in a divorce and lets us know how hard it is to keeo things friendly and loving in the midst of a system that makes every decision feel that much definitive and cruel. Every character is well written and I think this might be the best work that Baumbach hast put out to this date. Not only that, but this might be one of the best dramas with Divorce as its main topic right there along Kramer vs Kramer.

title: Two unlikeable people and their unlikeable kid get a divorce
review: In short Marriage has been destroyed by Divorce courts its the destroyer of Worlds but hey it's fashionable trendy loco and you wonder why there are incels and big pharma is rich by selling loads of anti-anxiety meds to kids from broken homes and parents have them to. Kramer Vs Kramer 2: the squeakquel revenge of the fallen judgement day etc. The father is the playwright, director stage company head honcho dude and the mother is the failed movie actor star of the plays. They both want big careers but have a kid it's one of those movies well done in areas. The lovey dovey actor stuff in this is both funny and cringe maybe that's the point. They are after all special. Man why were all the characters so unlikeable even the kid was a mothered little you know what, however he came off like the selfish parents that made him that way getting everything he wants. I looked at reviews such as "these people are privileged and white" which is racist in many ways, so black and brown people can't be privileged and successful huh?yeah I get what you are in trying to be woke you look worse. These people worked hard and have made money and get grants the mother may have well off parents most people in film do, black and brown people also get born into privilege and work to attain it so don't throw around that stale 2016 buzzword it's a trope in life now and a cliché and it shows a very narrow view of life. Also isn't Adam Driver Jewish? All people of any race can be privileged and narcissistic, go to Hollywood. I both liked and hated this film it made the father seem like a clichéd idiot that can't even pick what he wants to eat on a menu to the mother being an alcoholic that overtly mother's the son. It's almost 2d in its depiction of marriage and mothers and fathers yet they both want successful careers at the expense of their son yet they obviously love him. Then it would be 3d in its depiction of parents as they have honest reactions that they give each other as the divorce heats up that is fueled by divorce lawyers and the system which is very predatory and pantomimish, almost turning the parents and divorce into jerry springer characters. The feminist angle in this is funny that the female lawyer espoused that mothers are held up to a higher standard than father's seeing how I've seen women get away with smashing a glass in a man's throat with a "just grow up" from the judge as they do no time. No, women have no privelege. Most father's get screwed in divorce court to have a female lawyer spout out all that jargon about mother's being held to a higher standard almost had me fooled. Linda Hunt as the lawyer was good would rather of had a drama about Ray Liota Vs Linda Hunt divorce lawyer satire maybe? Make it happen Netflix. At times this movie had music that felt like it was in another movie like As good as it gets but this was not a happy ending it made no sense that your wife still loves you but she is dating someone else? I mean the reading of the letter left me thinking the mother actor was a lunatic that she would do things contrary to her beliefs then she confesses that she understands why her husband loved his work so much and neglected her because she has become him at the end lol making her look like a hypocrite. I think the Mother just wanted back on that carrousel that women go on in their 20s but without the reality. It also seemed as if the director took side mostly with the wife making her almost perfect and her problems were not focused on enough in the movie. neither of the characters had any self awareness either which is a writing problem these days. It had mixed messages to be honest you know when Patrick Bateman says,"this confession has meant nothing" in American Psycho? I felt that at the end that the directors confession about marriage meant nothing. No new information was found. I felt jipped out of a profound message that it was just some pretentious socialites complaining about life whilst off screen some homeless guy fights a rat over a slice of pizza. They should have added that guy into the mix. Overrated but at least better than most Netflix movies which are shocking bland.

title: If you like a good divorce story, here it is.
review:
Marriage Story is about divorce. It's about the unraveling of individual commitments to each other, and the pain that occurs when one, or both changes their mind.

The film doesn't plow any new ground, this story has been told before. It does showcase some important performances; like Adam Drivers' and Laura Dern's. But the story is worn-out that I had trouble paying attention. It was ver predictable.

One significant moment was Driver's solo performance singing. THAT song's lyrics made me cry.

title: Worst! Another overrated movie!
review:
Another overrated, without music La La Land movie. It doesn't show anything useful but it shows 'how to destroy your own marriage by yourself' + miscommunication and ego.
To be honest, I don't feel this movie deserves any award at all. Of course actors did their part well like another normal movie. But the script is so poorly written. Divorce is not the only choice for small problems. But this stupid film encouraging divorce over every little thing. 💩
Therefore, awards and nominations are sooooo overrated 😞😞

title: Who wrote this boring script?
review: Good acting, poorly written, the script puts you to sleep. Another movie with good actors and terrible writers.

title: Disappointing and boring
review: I mean what was the point of this movie? I was baring all the boredom till the end only to be utterly disappointed. I am perfectly fine with the divorce. But I was just disappointed with the way it ended. Either it has to be all bitter or happily ever after. It can't be in the middle and it will never be. Just waste of time I would say.

title: Boring Boring Boring
review:
Really 8.1? I really tried to see this movie but there is nothing there. I live this kind of life. I want to see a movie to escape reality and not to live it one more time.
Maybe 2 out of 10 only for the acting ot this great two.

title: Frankly... soporific
review: Johansson and Driver may be great on their actings, but the film is soporific. Nothing memorable in it. I personally think that misses the opportunity to transfer the alleged hurt and drama to the spectator.

title: Depressing, I really felt for Charlie
review: At the beginning of the movie, I felt for Nicole. She wanted to be seen, I got that. Throughout the movie though, she became more and more the villain and less the victim. Charlie was simply a father with big dreams and a loving heart. His upset with his wife could have been fixed if she had simply tried to work it out and discuss the problem, rather than jumping to divorce. Nicole took all of Charlie's money and broke his spirits, and Charlie allowed his spirits to be broke because he wanted to be close to his son. I really felt for Charlie, and I was depressed as hell at the end because of what became of him. He deserved better.

title: Absolutely Flat
review:
Sorry but
I thought the ending is gonna be something WOW or plot twist or mind blowing. But really this is absolutely boring, flat and wasting time.
Acting is good, but yet again story way is boring and you will never understand the meaning of this movie even if you try to like it and try not to blink your eyes while watching it wouldn't help.

title: Slow and boring
review:
After all the hype and awards this movie received I wanted to see it for myself.
Found it to be so slow and boring that I gave up half way through. Guess it's not everyone's cup of tea.

title: Good story, but...
review: A good movie, good story, the artists gave a performance show, but there is no way not to compare, without the fluidity and creativity of the Woody Allen movies, some scenes get a little tiring and "forced".

title: Boring.....
review:
I don't find people that are miserable all the time entertaining.
Sorry...

title: Worst film ive seen in a long time.
review: Save yourself 2hours of your life please. This is not an 8/10. If you do, good luck.

title: Boring
review: I've try to watch the whole thing but i found it so damn boring

title: Not a masterpiece, but good
review:
The fight scene was genuine. I will say that. You really believe they hate each other. However, Nicole's attorney seems to be the one goading her on to "get this, get that". Was Nicole always this way, deep down? Not a true artist, but just someone out to get what she can? It seems like that. But I would sure feel uncomfortable if my divorce attorney took off her shoes and cuddled up with me on the couch in her office. Am I hiring you? Are we sisters? What's about to happen here? Creepy.

Even more creepy is the non-blinking, robotic evaluator Ms. Katz, who doesn't even have the correct address, doesn't smile, doesn't have a shred of engagement at all, and seems to be in this job solely for the check. She sits there staring at you. She stands there staring at you. She doesn't check out the whole apartment like, say, a child welfare worker would to see how you live or even if the entire place is presentable for a kid to live in. She tells us the obvious. "New York is a long way from here." Anyone knows that. It isn't for her to say. That whole scene with her annoyed me. Plus the thing with him and the knife made him look extra bad. He didn't have to bring it up again. She didn't ask him - she just did her staring thing.

I'm glad I never got divorced if it meant I had to deal with people like this - uncomfortable divorce attorneys and staring evaluators. Wow.

title: Artistic maturity start for Scarlett?
review:
This role can be one of the pilon of artistic maturity for Scarlett Johansson. Combining theatre with movie can/must be in her benefit! For Adam Driver also!
But the transaction from theatre to movie & reverse must be done in the english way! That's the right way! 7 stars are for director recipe, rest of stars(10;)) going to the Scarlett & Adam!

title: Its slow but beautiful
review: Made me feel i want to face my problems and feel alive. Nothing better to say.

title: I saw myself reflected on this characters.
review: The film deals with a very heavy subject, divorce and life moving forward sharing a kid but it does it very graciously, with a dose of humor. I cried almost the entire time. Very convincing acting delivered by both main characters.

title: Unfortunately, Overrated
review: Unfortunately, I had read 2 reviews of this film before seeing it. I do my best to avoid (and usually succeed) in avoiding previews. I did so with "Marriage Story". I always want to be surprised. For this film, this was nearly unavoidable. The studio was almost always shoving the film down my throat. Even if they hadn't done this, I had some expectations given the cast and crew. I am a big fan of Ms Johansson, and for a long time. She has very potent acting skills. Regardless, I was drawn into the story from the start of the film. The characters are very believable. Sadly, the script devolves into blandness. This is not the fault of the actors. After about 40 minutes, I simply did not care what would happen next. Overall, I found it forgettable. Better luck next time.

title: This film is fuelled solely by emotion, and it never runs out.
review: Excellent and realistic separation drama analyzes the back and forth of a divorce and emphasizes how the legal procedure actually boosts and preys on the split; superb cast throughout, but Laura Dern is absolutetly amazing.

title: I 'm so lonely
review:
Women have minds and they have souls and they have ambitions ... I 'm so sick of people saying that love is all a woman is fit for. I 'm so sick of it ...

But I 'm so lonely.

After Jo said this, I couldn't help crying with her.

And when Jo got Shakespeare, I remembered that my friends sent me a few meters of pictures in junior high school. The feeling that my little talent is cherished by people is probably the best thing in the world.

title: Great acting, but average script.
review: A lot of unnecessary scenes, but this covers a diifficult subject quite accurately. People should watch this before considering divorce, or perhaps before getting married in the first place.

title: It is a good one but nothing more than that
review:
There is no need to say Marrige Story is a movie is nicely acted and carefully completed, it is not easy to understand why this movie accepted as a ''Masterpiece''

It has found a avarage place amongst the dozens of such film that I watched before since it is not have any remarkable scenes. Eventually it is a good one but not a Masterpiece

title: Getting some great reviews
review: This film was enjoyable and very depressing as most reviews would say. This film is about the aftermath of a marriage and not a story about a marriage. The acting is brilliant and the story is entertaining. If you have ever lived through a divorce this film would a lot more impactful to the viewer. I have not but watching this is just a 2 plus hour argument of a divorcing couple. The acting and story felt very authentic with the help of the two leads. In the end the two main characters did not really change and during the course of the film the viewer had no idea who to root for. They both like everyone in the world had flaws with ups and downs but in the end after it all the conclusion was to just spend all their money to fight for their son. Where two fight for their son or just ego? I guess that is for the audience to figure out.

title: Hit so close to home that it was uncomfortable. ..
review: If you've been married for a while or going through a divorce oh my.... I don't think you'll feel good but you will identify with it. The acting is raw in that really refreshing good way. (Like in Girls.) Surprising moments. Just great stuff. Their son. Wow! I was blown away by him. Was he even acting? Soooo realistic! I put off this movie because I thought it would be cheesey and predictable or just clichÃ© or Woodyallenesk but it wasn't. Worth watching. Only negative: all white cast with some color in the background....

title: Kinda stunned of most males reviewing this movie
review:
The movie itself is not a story you have never heard before. But the performances by the lead actor and actress is what makes it special. Well worth the rating of 8,1. I feel like Adam just feels so genuine in whatever he does. There is something about this authenticity he brings to his roles that is very special.

SPOILERS!!!

After viewing it I am amazed how many men have reviewed the movie that say they sided with Charlie from the beginning and never swayed back and forth! I watched it with my man so luckily I know not all men have the same lack of emotional empathy. I as a woman swayed back and forth and tbh I say you must be a woman hating if you couldnt see it from her point of view ever.

Believe me, if it was a movie where the roles were reversed - and a male gave up all of his personality and life to cater to a woman's dreams for 10 years, where the man moved away from his family, was being critiqued by the woman in the way he acted, even had his hair and the woman asked the man to put whatever money he made into her dream - AND then she cheated on him AND then she expected him to praise her for all the men she didn't have sex with while she had the chance...you would NEVER see any man feel the least bit sorry for the woman being forced to then give up her dream and have to actually also adjust so the man could find himself and be close with his family where he came from.

So. If you seriously never ever swayed to her side - there is something wrong with your emotional range and the way you view women.

title: Amazing performance by Driver and Johansson (not so much).
review: I did not have any expectations when i sat down to watch this movie, did not even knew the plot. I got engaged when the "nice things each other" scenes finished and the reality was presented. To be honest, not a big fan of Scarlett and have not seen any of the movies that Adam was in, however, AMAZING performance by him, truly talanted actor! Scarlett was also very good, however I think that Adam built the character really well!

title: The story we all know, but get to see from ouside and feel it deeply
review:
I usually fall asleep at movies, yes even at the cinema. There's something about those reassuring voices that makes me feel so safe, that I can take a nap. So, when once in a blue moon, a film keeps me interested all the way till the end, without reaching for the fast forward button, or yawning because "oh the plot holes - oh the inconsistency etc." I know I've found something special. This movie, this experience, had me pressing "pause" from time to time because it was too much, in the best way possible.
Yes, it has the whole boy/girl meets girl/boy (or whatever you fancy) formula, but it's not some random person meeting another and then breaking-up over a bunch of lemons or tiny stupidity, because we just want to see them fight, because we're drawn to drama and conflict while eating popcorn. No, these two had very good and real reasons for each step of their relationship. And, oh, boy, if you were ever in one of the roles: child of divorce, the one that thinks he/she is kind but actually is selfish, the one that acts like a victim - always blaming others of their misfortune AND choices, or just an overall mess, not figuring where to go next - regardless of age or career - this, THIS will hit you, this will open your eyes, will make you huff and puff occasionally. I started arguing with the screen at certain points.
So, of course, watch it. There's no right or wrong moment when to do is, like, you'll see, even if you try to take sides, you just can't. Because humanity means not being just one thing, means being the good and the bad guy at the same time. It means we have no idea what we're doing and no matter how much you try, someone will get hurt. This is a movie/story about two good people in a bad situation.
On the acting side: I think this is the dream. To act so good it feels 100% natural, yet, it's all mastery and control and well placed emotion. This story is good on it's own, but these people make it LIFE on screen. Hat tip to the supporting characters as well: everyone was so well placed, it never felt fake.
It's great that my first review is about this beauty, that, if you really let it, will shake you, nicely and delicately, to your very core. And you'll appreciate more the ones that love you and the ones you love.

title: Moving, family-oriented tearjerker.
review: This movie revolves around a family, in which the couple is going through divorce. Spoiler alert: Nicole who is an actress is fed up with the emptiness and obliviousness of Charlie who is a theater director wants a divorce. Both of them are battling for the custody of their child, Henry. Through thick and thins of the divorce battle, they find a common ground on which they can be friends without hurting their child.

title: Not bad but not that good
review: Actually my rating should have been a 7 but i gave 6 to balance its overratedness. It might be better if it was a little bit shorter. It was emotional but also some boring.

title: Good
review: This was actually a good movie. I am a movie fanatic so it was easy for me to guess the ending 30 mins in. I like how this movie depict the ugly side of marriage, this isn't a typical movie about marriage. It was very good and very well played by the actors.

title: Nice story about how not to ruin your kid's life
review: I love the genuine acting tho it's your typical unrealistic "were all model looking and rich" American movie!

title: Best movie of this year... NOT!
review:
To slow, to weird acted, two long, to boring.

Technically good, decent and good pictured.

The character of miss johannsen is weird tho.

In total I didn't like the movie at all.

title: YOU'VE BEEN SERVED
review:
The reason this is rating high initially is because the commonality so many have with this season of life. The empathy many would feel with both couples plight will simply keep them watching.

Right from the beginning you can tell you are dealing with a lower budget Netflix movie not the spectacle of a studio production.

I almost tapped out of the long dialogue scenes in the first act, getting comfortable with the cliche feminist lawyer was not witty or clever.

The acting was forced in so many scenes, and the initial stages of the relationship breakdown were virtually ignored and a fatal flaw, this coupled with the amicable conversation right after a monstering by both lawyers in the courtroom was just a failure in the believability of the script.

What you are left with is sequences of raw emotion that force you to pick a side down gender lines, which was the only thing that really held the plot together which was nothing more than another custody battle brought to life.

The redeeming moment of a Brady bunch all learning to live together is a feel good resolution that must have taken 3 minutes to think of. I understand if this is enough for you to rate this film high after the real life roller coaster that so many of us have been on but as a lay film critic, I really expect more.

Sorry x

title: A boring, tedious, at times annoying movie with great acting
review: Noah Baumbach's Marriage Story is one of the most overrated films of the year. I really can't say too much about the movie, not because I don't want to talk about it, it's because there is barely anything to talk about with this film. The acting for the most part is very well done, particularly from Adam Driver, and I actually really like the opening scene, but after that, the film because a chore to get through. This movie is so boring! Hardly anything of note happens in it! It is also way too long, I was constantly checking the runtime and seeing how much I had left until it was over. I didn't care about any of these characters, I didn't feel bad for them, sometimes they become so annoying that it is unbearable. So yeah, this movie is way too overhyped, it's just simply boring Oscar bait to me.

title: Do not waste your time on this one
review: At the beginning it seemed to be a good movie, after some minutes I just wanted the movie to end and finally go to sleep, unfortunately I could not do it because there were more people watching it with me. It has some good parts but in overall it is just completely boring and not worthy at all. I think some people like it because they went through the same situation in their life. In brief, as somebody said before, this movie is painfully boring.

title: Hollywood Hogwash
review: There were some bits in the middle that weren't too bad but either side it was sentimental self indulgence with too much tinkly music in the background. The acting was mostly very good and we didn't give up so it got 2 stars but it was touch and go.

title: Not entirely terrible.
review: People have a tendency to overrate such brand of movies and use terms like honest and real while describing it. And yet, the behaviour of the leads are nothing like real human beings. There's the Fight which does show glimpses of that real scenario and not surprisingly it's the best part of the movie. Scarlett J has done her best to make herself as appealing as a non living object and it's Adam Driver who drives the plot when it actually works. Special mention to that one "KNIFE" scene which is the funniest I've laughed in a while. And special mention to the first 40 minutes that has no audio pauses and the ceaseless and pointless blabbering that hurts the mind/ears. Also, the kid is a spoilt annoyance and has too much screen time.

title: Hollywood Indulgence
review: Another of these Hollywood indulgent movies that really has no plot, no storyline and is basically a waste of good talent. Acting is A+ but the Marriage Story is like watching a depressing reality tv show that has no direction and you could watch it in reverse and not know the difference. If your not depressed enough with the world then watch this!

title: Saw 15 minutes and got bored
review:
Marriage Story is the latest Netflix movie starring Scarlett Johansson and Adam Driver and tells the tale of a young couple with a kid who are on the verge of a divorce. I couldn't get into the film. Maybe I'll give it another chance again but this was one overrated movie.

Ended up watching Bad Boys 1 on Netflix instead.

title: yawn
review:
For me and my wife we found it it incredibly boring, really wanted to turn it off after half the movie, but we watched the whole bore fest
sorry just our opinion
4/10
wish I could have the 2 hours of my life back

title: Why wouldn't we speak
review:
The movie looks good from the perspective of "drama", until you look through the scenario and the decisions the main characters made during the whole movie.

1. We (the audience) haven't seen that Nicole actually discussed what makes her unhappy with her husband (Chris) or anyhow tried to solve her own life with him, but acted only behind his back ruining the family.

2. Every lawyer wants earn big using unhappy family as their 'successful' portfolio, and no layer would advise such a Nicole to simply talk to her husband and tell him what she feels before attacking taking everything he have earned. The layer was the only one character in the movie who played on the family, basically destroying it, and of course, got a nice profit.

3. I would understand Nicole's unhappy live with her husband if he hadn't care about her, but he basically made her a Star. She reached her dream, and only then decided to divorce him when she doesn't need him anymore.

4. During the whole movie we see how Chris was pushed. Is he such a bad man? He cheated, but this wasn't the main point the movie was trying to emphasize. Should we (the women) now divorce every time the men don't listen to us, to what we want without any explanation?

5. I have been waiting for a moment when they finally discuss their problems together. All they shouted was not about what they DID and want to GET from each other (except Chris's cheated), but how they ARE bad for each other. The movie teaches well how to break any relationships and at the same time it says - "So we shouldn't even try to listen to each other."

The moral part of the movie stays pathetic. The family was ruined because Nicole managed to tell her problem only to the lawyer. Yes, she's got what she wanted, but was she happy after? It didn't seem so in the end.

I'm scared to see that people consider this movie as something "wonderful". It teaches us to do stupid stuff without thinking that it may hurt someone we love

title: Who are these people giving it such high ratings?
review: I only watched this because of Driver as I'm not a Scarlett fan. Wow, long, slow and boring. Waiting for it to pick up and it never did. Realistic divorce? How many people can fly home on a whim just to go trick or treating with your kid? These are rich people's problems. Actors, oy. Over dramatic, self indulged people, I see the realism there, I'm sure this is how Hollywood does divorce. People crying? Maybe they were bored to tears like me. I can't believe all the praise for this.

title: What a disappointment
review: Along with"Her" and "Roma", on of the three worst movies of the decade. This is what Hollywood and New York think of marriage and divorce lawyers. We never found out how she initially wanted out of the marriage. And her lawyer was all hugs and lovey doves instead of being a professional lawyer. I can see why left coast and right coast would love this movie but not in the other 48.

title: I Wanted to Love it, but...
review:
With all the critics raving & such a stellar cast, I thought "how could it go wrong?" But go wrong, it did. I gave up after an hour, most of which, saw Nicole in tears. The pacing is off - odd & disjointed. This film doesn't seem to know whether it wants to be a comedy or drama, so there are scenes of one or the other, slipping ungracefully into the next. The parents are borderline abusive towards their son, who is used here as a prop whom they can haggle over. The farcical scene leading towards Charles being served was cringe-inducing and overly long (since when does an old lady leap into the arms of her daughter's husband? Yes, I know wine was involved but everyone in the room acted like it was Tuesday). If Nicole stopped mid-way through explaining her story to her attorney to exclaim about how yummy the refreshments were one more time, I was going to throw something at the screen. Stop it, just stop it. Only crazy people act like that. Nicole is bratty, whiny and a couple sandwiches short of a picnic. Charlie is hang dog, wooden, stoic and largely unpleasant. I don't want to spend 5 minutes with these people let alone 2 hours! The only thing I can think of that would explain why film critics are raving is the cast of luminaries & the self-referential Hollywood/TV production sub plot. Critics eat that stuff up (see La La Land & Once Upon a Time...).
Depressing, charmless, visually uninteresting. Now if you'll excuse me, I'm going to go watch Joker to life my spirits...

title: Ugh, So must talent b wasted
review:
I love everyone affiliated with this show
But DANG y'all make me hate life with this tireless story of two people who can't sort s-it. Get it together. I understand life is sh-t, people r sh-t and there are many misunderstandings, but 2hrs of that? Thank you kindly, I'm off to the pub! And sort ur sh-t, u had a disagreement don't mean throw the whole thing to an end!

title: Honestly not sure how to rate this
review: This movie made me feel nothing. I wasn't disappointed, I wasn't upset, I wasn't happy, which is always a bad sign. Movies SHOULD make you feel something, whether bad or good, but I had no emotional connection to any of the characters, it didn't feel like they had any chemistry either and you'd have to remind yourself that they're supposed to be married. You don't know who you should be rooting for, and by the end you don't remember what you've been doing for the past 2 hours.
