And all couples in this world, under such a downward trend, will they do better or worse? The good memories they once had about each other became so heartbreaking at the moment of emotional breakdown, but this is marriage.

title: Overloaded Melodrama
review:
Packed with good performances and intensions.
I have doubts whether Noah Baumbach is a real person or a Woody Allen character that became a director. Marriage Story is tender and witty and a bit caricaturish.

title: Moving and Delicate
review: I was really moved by this film. The soundtrack by Randy Newman really evokes a feeling of nostalgia and memories which really help bring out the tears during the movie, much like his soundtracks to the Toy Story films. And the tracks really compliment each scene, I noticed especially during the ending, which is where I finally cried. This is also thanks to an incredible performance from Adam Driver who really gives it his all here and despite his character not being a perfect person, you really do genuinely care about him and during some of the later scenes, his emotions start to properly come out and that's when I began to cry. The cinematography is also extremely well done and there are a lot of shots that symbolically divide the two leads and it subconsciously gives a feeling of sadness. It's shot very still and unmoving in a good way and it helps set the tone and pace of the film, which is slow yet extremely emotionally impactful, especially in the latter areas of the movie. It's just a really solid, unique and compassionate look into the real struggles of a divorce and throughout the whole film, you feel bad for both sides of the party for different reasons. And when the movie comes to a close and the two finalise the split while still maintaining a stable family life with their son, you feel a sense of melancholy relief. The letter reading scene at the end was honestly in my top 10 movie scenes of the year it was that damn touching. I think this was the right film for me to watch especially with me feeling really down recently, and it's a flick with lots of heart, solid writing, incredible acting, a stellar soundtrack and a real punch to the heart. If you're interested, watch it. It's truly one of the best of last year. Well done Noah Baumbach.

title: Movie does not convey much in optimistic sense
review: Acting screenplay is good but story wise i found tad bit boring. When Charlie hires a attorney and he says you are the one only person saw me as human with emotion, i felt movie might turn up on good or optimistic note but it didn't.

title: Marriage Story
review: What separates Marriage Story from the rest of Baumbach's filmography is that it could have wallowed in pessimism, but there is love and tenderness coursing through its veins.Baumbach is an expert farceur.

A few minor pacing issues but definitely a 9.5/10 movie (Adam driver should of one best actor)

Although the American system is complex and sometimes ridiculous (such as sending an observer to observe the confusion and awkwardness of how fathers and children get along), it is generally quite human, unable to live together and still the closest family member, unable to refuse to acknowledge the existing feelings. On the part of the actors, johansson's performance has been very stylized, can not walk out of her early fire of that set; And Adam is the treasure actor. He's so good. It's all about him. A lot of brilliant acting sequences, a lot of golden lines, a lot of funny moments, a sad and funny film, a new reflection on modern couples: "the virgin Mary gave birth to Jesus when she was still a virgin.

The main story of this movie is about divorcing. but is that really what they want us to see? no this is "Marriage Story" from the time they met each other, got marriage, have kid , conflict. and divorcing.
this movie is showing us so many conflicts around all of us. around all of things, life, carriers, family, love.etc.. but still what they made still lives somewhere in their hearts.
all things around us has 2 side, good and bad, light and darkness, happiness and sadness. director and actor, wife and husband, and starting and ending. those things sounds like totally opposite from each other ,but still both admit each other to make this world.even if things gets harder , there are still hope ,even if they decided to live their own way, there are still love in them.
even just one little word can change and remind them how great they went through.
this is definitely beautiful movie.

title: Main Actress
review: I wish someone else was playing Nicole, the movie would be much better...

title: Marriage Story
review: I heard about this film during Awards Season, made by Netflix it was receiving many nominations in various categories at the big award ceremonies, and it was rated well, so I looked forward to it. Basically, Charlie Barber (Oscar, BAFTA and Golden Globe nominated Adam Driver) is a successful theatre director in New York City, and his wife Nicole (Oscar, BAFTA and Golden Globe nominated Scarlett Johansson), a former teen film actress, is the star of the company's latest production. The couple is experiencing marital troubles and sees a Mediator (Robert Smigel), who suggests that they both write down what they like about each another. But Nicole is too embarrassed to read hers aloud and they decide to abandon marriage counselling. Nicole is offered a starring role in a TV pilot in Los Angeles, so she decides to leave the theatre company and live temporarily in West Hollywood with her mother, taking the couple's young son Henry (Azhy Robertson) with her. Charlie decides to stay in New York, as the play will be eventually moving to Broadway. Despite the couple agreeing to split the divorce settlement amicably and have no lawyers, Nicole hires family lawyer Nora Fanshaw (Oscar, BAFTA and Golden Globe winning Laura Dern). Nicole tells Nora the full story of her relationship with Charlie, the gradual feelings of neglect by him and how he rejects her ideas and desires. Nicole also mentions that she thinks Charlie cheated and slept with the stage manager of the theatre company. Charlie travels to Los Angeles to visit his family, revealing that he has won a MacArthur Fellowship grant, but Nicole serves him divorce papers. Charlie meets with brash and expensive lawyer Jay Marotta (Ray Liotta) who urges him to fight dirty, but Charlie returns to New York without hiring him. Nora calls Charlie and urges him to get a lawyer soon or risk losing custody of Henry. Charlie returns to Los Angeles and hires empathetic and retired family lawyer Bert Spitz (Alan Alda), who goes for a more civil and calm approach. On Bert's advice, Charlie rents an apartment in Los Angeles to be closer to his family and strengthen his custody case. Charles wishes to avoid going to court, so Bert arranges a meeting with Nora and Nicole. Nora argues that Charlie had little respect for Nicole's wishes to move back to Los Angeles and that Henry would prefer to stay with his mother rather than flying back and forth. Bert privately advises Charlie to leave his New York residency, but a frustrated Charlie refuses and decides to fire him. Using his MacArthur Fellowship grant money, Charlie hires Jay. The case moves to court, where Nora and Jay argue aggressively on behalf of their clients and attempt to portray the other party in a negative way. Nora highlights Charlie's past infidelity and emotional distance, while Jay exaggerates Nicole's drinking habits as alcoholism and mentions hacking into Charlie's emails. Meanwhile, Charlie and Nicole remain friendly out of court and share time with Henry, who is increasingly annoyed with the constant moving. The couple are embittered with the legal process and decide to meet in private to talk things through. The discussion starts calmly and friendly, but eventually becomes a bitter argument. Nicole claims he has truly become selfish, and Charlie punches the wall and says he wishes that she would die. He then breaks down in shame and apologises; Nicole comforts him. Expert evaluator Nancy Katz (Martha Kelly) monitors a night in with Charlie and Henry, during which Charlie accidentally cuts himself. Soon after, the couple agree to reach an equal agreement to finalise the divorce, although Nora negotiates slightly better terms for Nicole, against her wishes. One year later, Charlie play has been a success in Broadway, while Nicole has a new boyfriend and is nominated for an Emmy Award for directing an episode of her show. Charlie informs Nicole that he will be living in Los Angeles full-time to be closer to Henry. Later, he discovers Henry reading Nicole's list of things she likes about Charlie she wrote down during counselling. Henry asks Charlie to read it aloud to him, he does so, becoming emotional as Nicole watches from afar. That evening, following a Halloween party, Nicole offers to let Charlie take Henry home even though it is her night with him. As Charlie walks out to his car carrying a sleeping Henry, he Nicole smile at each other, and they part ways once more. Also starring Wallace Shawn as Frank. Johansson and Driver both give exceptional performances as the separating couple who try to remain friendly through a difficult process, their highlight is the argument, it is good to see Liotta and Alda appear as well, but Dern does almost steal the show in most of her scenes, including a magnificent monologue moment. The title is probably deliberately misleading, as it is about a marriage ending, it gets ugly when the lawyers get involved and the custody battle gets heated, it is well written, with moving and emotional moments, but a little room for humour also, it is a worthwhile drama. It was nominated the Oscars for Best Motion Picture of the Year for Best Original Screenplay, and Best Music (Original Score) for Randy Newman, it was nominated the BAFTAs for Best Original Screenplay, and Best Casting, and it was nominated the Golden Globe for Best Screenplay, Best Original Score, and Best Motion Picture - Drama. Very good!

title: well performed
review:
Action is on point in this movie. doesnt come over as over the top, and when you feel like it does, its justified. storywise its a bit stale. camerawork is done well, with the use of static and dinamic shots in the same scenes. overall a good movie, but not good enough for me to keep me interested 100% of the time.

6/10: very good acting, but sub par story

title: Not the Best, but Not the Worst
review:
Personally, I have been putting off seeing the critically acclaimed film Marriage Story directed by Noah Baumbach. People have been telling me to watch this film since December and I didn't really want to watch a film about a divorce around the happy holiday season. Also, I have heard from multiple sources that this film deserves all the awards that it had been nominated for and I was worried that the film wouldn't exceed my high expectations thanks to my sources. They were right, for the most part. I personally did like the film, but I can not say that I would want to watch it again.
Marriage Story is about a married couple that would like to get a divorce. Charlie (Adam Driver) wants to stay in New York and his soon to be ex-wife, Nicole (Scarlett Johansson) would like to move and stay in Los Angeles, they also have a child which just makes things much more difficult. This film accurately represents both sides of a divorce and in the end, you really do find yourself rooting for both sides. I personally think the scene where Charlie (Adam Driver) reads Nicoles (Scarlett Johansson) letter is really impactful to show how much they really loved each other and also why they needed to get a divorce. In the scene, their son Henry is trying to read the letter to his dad and he reads, "He rarely gets defeated, which I feel like I always do." Nicole writes this letter to read to Charlie in the beginning of the movie, but she never does because she says she didn't like what she wrote.
Yes, the film is a good film, but I don't think I would personally see it again. The whole movie is about a divorce and it's almost two and a half hours long. In my opinion, this is not the usual type of movie I would find myself picking out to watch on a Saturday night. At some parts of the movie, it did drag on a bit, but I feel the acting of Adam Driver, Scarlett Johansson, Laura Dern, and many more definitely made up for the longevity of the movie. Noah Baumbach also directed the film, The Squid and the Whale, which is also a divorce story but not nearly as long. There are other movies that are also over two hours long, like Forrest Gump. When watching Forrest Gump, you don't feel like the movie is being dragged out to continue making the same point throughout the entire movie. I think, if maybe the movie wasn't over two hours long, more viewers would be interested.
In the film, Noah Baumbach uses many different techniques especially in point of view and costume/makeup. Throughout the movie, I feel the viewers can really understand how each character is feeling about the entire situation. We get an inside view of how Charlies friends are feeling, how Nicole's mother is feeling, and even how their child is feeling. I feel we really get everyone's perspective towards the divorce and separation. I also feel like we really get to see how the characters are feeling by what color their outfit is in some scenes. For example, in a scene where Charlie gets frustrated and angry, he is clearly wearing red to show the emotion that Baumbach wanted to portray.
I can not say the film, Marriage Story, was my favorite. But I can say that I appreciate the acting and the idea of the film. I just feel it could have been much better if it was just a bit shorter. But, I can say that if you have been through a divorce or you have seen one first hand, you may find this film to be more emotional for you. As for me, I can not say that it is my favorite nor will I be watching it again.

title: Well acted scenes do not pull together
review:
Noah Baumbach is one of those filmmakers that is highly regarded in the "Art House" community for his semi-autobiographical humanistic films. These are domestic dramas heavy on dialogue - the type of film that "A-List" Actors swarm to perform in for the acting challenges it brings. His latest, MARRIAGE STORY, is no exception as it follows the dissolution of a marriage and the struggles of the 2 main players involved. The husband and wife are written realistically (according to Baumbach) with moments of pathos and moments of repulsion thrown in at equal measure.

So, naturally, Baumbach (THE SQUID AND THE WHALE) was able to draw 2 of the better performers working in film today to play the leads - Scarlett Johannson and Adam Driver - and they deliver the goods (along with Laura Dern) - all 3 were deserved Oscar nominees - and the performances of ALL of the actors on screen are worth watching.

But...that's about all this film has going for it. For I found the first hour and a half of this film tedious with (at times) preposterous dialogue that looked good on paper - and was enthusiastically performed - but wrang (at least to me) as unrealistic. Consequently, this film is filled with well acted scenes that I kept saying to myself - "that was a well acted scene and that was an interesting choice that that actor made in that scene", but I found that these disparate scenes in this part of the film did not hold together as a movie. It seemed to me a series of acting class scenes and not a film.

And, for that, I blame Writer/Director Baumbach. This film, purportedly, parallels his divorce from actress Jennifer Jason Leigh (HATEFUL 8) and it shows. It's a little too "on the nose" and "inside baseball" for my tastes. The dialogue, at times, was "too cute" and the pacing was deliberate - which is a nice way of saying "slow".

What saves this film is the performances. Johannson dominates the first part of this film and she brings her "A" game, bringing a strength and awakening purpose to her character that will have you rooting for her - at the beginning. The first half of the film (for the most part) is Johannson's film and is what gives her her Oscar nomination (she won't win), but she deserves the nomination.

Laura Dern is also Oscar nominated for her role as Johannson's Divorce Attorney. Bright, funny, articulate and a shark in the courtroom and boardroom, Dern's character was fascinating to watch onscreen. While I thought this performance was "fine" and I was "okay" with it getting an Oscar nomination, I kept waiting for the "Oscar scene" for this supporting character - and about 2/3 of the way into the film this character had that moment - and Dern killed it. I would now say Dern is the deserved frontrunner for Best Supporting Actress (ironically, over Johansson who is ALSO nominated for Supporting Actress for JoJo Rabbit).

This scene propels the last 1/3 of this film into interesting territory - a place that this film had not gone to thus far. I was sucked into this last part and I think it is in no small reason due to the fact that this part of the film is driven (no pun intended) by Adam Driver's character. I've always found Driver to be a fascinating actor and while his character was not front and center much in the first part of the film, he commands center stage in the last part and I could not take my eyes off of his powerful performance. In a strong year of Best Acting performances, he shines and I would be happily surprised and satisfied if he won the Best Actor Oscar.

Alan Alda, as usual, brings an interesting character to the screen as does Julie Hagerty (remember her from AIRPLANE?) as Scarlett's mother. The surprise to me was the strong play of Ray Liotta as one of Driver's lawyers - it is his best work in quite some time and shows he does have some acting chops. Finally, good ol' Wallace Shawn (the "inconceivable" Count Visini in PRINCESS BRIDE) was fun - and annoying - in his scenes.

So...if you want to see some good acting in scenes that I am sure will end up as good scenes in an acting class performed very strongly, then check out MARRIAGE STORY. Just make sure you are well rested. A fast-paced romp it is not.

Letter Grade: B (for the strong performances)

7 stars (out of 10) and you can take that to the Bank(ofMarquis)

title: A hate letter to Los Angeles
review:
Do you want to hate Los Angeles? Then come here and do all of the clichÃ© things that tourists do such as walking down Sunset Boulevard, and go to Universal Studios. Hey, on the weekend, just switch states and check out Vegas!

Do you want to love Los Angeles? Go on a hike up through Will Rogers State Park and see a performance at the Walt Disney Concert Hall. Stay in California for the weekend and spend it in Joshua Tree.

Another way to hate Los Angeles is to watch this film! I'm a native of LA; I've traveled the world and I live here again. I love my sprawling city, but this film made me want to leave forever and move to Manhattan.

Such typical east coast snobbery here, the shots of NY included the esoteric theater (or should I say theatre) company and the jazzy bar where the pretty girl you know is signing a tune... it was so romanticized and hence saccharin. The shots of LA were mostly of Adam Driver's character having a miserable time in a miserable apartment, surrounded by gritty mini malls. These places exist as part of the tapestry that makes LA diverse and interesting, and yet there is so much natural beauty too.

Geographical diatribe over, the film packs a powerful performance punch by Adam Driver. I did side and sympathize with him while interestingly my husband found the culpability rather balanced between the two main characters. Thumbs up.

title: all of it
review: It is all of it, lawyers, suffering, influence over mind, all of it and more that in another countries...

title: Love and hate a sad heartbeat
review:
"Story of a Marriage" is a difficult film to evaluate, since its core is to talk about the end of a marriage, the American-directed feature Noah Baumbarch is good but it didn't touch me, his sentimentality is strong, especially in the third act, but it is a contextual film, people who have experienced the same trauma will identify more and feel their pain, feeling and anguish at the top of their skin, which I was unable to feel.

As the name suggests, "Story of a Marriage" deals with the breakup of a relationship of an established couple and a child, the long brush outlines the reasons for the breakup but focuses on showing the consequences of a breakup, his drama sometimes escalating. too much, and its hatred and ramifications are strange in the very sense established and created by the film, but as already had, its conclusion is beautiful and poetic, a charming third act that concludes and circumvents its errors very effectively.

The direction is simple but has an exquisite use of the camera and framing, always highlighting the distance of the couple and opening up to monologues and views, which are always filled with great performances, the whole cast is fine, Adam Drive and Scarlett Johansson has phenomenal chemistry, and both actors are great in their roles.

"Marriage Story" is a good movie, it deserves and will take some Oscar nominations, but again, it's a very contextual movie that needs a previous viewer experience, those who don't have that traumatic experience, will see the qualities of the movie but will not feel all your sentimentality. NOTE 7/10

title: Good
review: It's really good, but I don't get the hype. I wasn't catched by it, and maybe that's on me. Anyway, is worth watching.

title: Excellent performance, but fail to relate on many levels
review:
Marriage Story is a good film but an overrated good film. It's at times great, but it doesn't work for me on many levels.

As someone who is going through a divorce myself, I just can't identify at all with Nicole. From the very beginning her grounds for divorce seems incredibly flimsy. Do a couple who are clearly still in love with each other decide to end it for the reasons given in the film? I can see why so many are labelling them as hipsters. Well... And Charlie at the end of the film wants to move to LA. Well... Are we supposed to sympathise?

As for the plot, there are just too many similarities to Synecdoche, New York. So the wife has decided to move to a far away place, and taking the child whom the husband fears he will never see. Then the husband is a theatre director who got a MacArthur grant, and is the love interest of a "lesser" female member of the theatre crew. And then a condescending female professional (lawyer / therapist) provides comedy relief. I mean, am I supposed to immerse myself in the plot when I am counting similarities of this plot with another plot?

And then there's more. So Nicole is an actress turned successful female director. How wonderful, guess who that reminds me of? I really hope Gerwig wouldn't mind getting written into a divorce drama while Baumbach is still with her. I am hoping Scarlett Johansson is not going to be the big screen witness to another director couple divorce (well she's technically not on big screen in Her but hey).

So you see, there are just too many elements stopping me emotionally investing in the characters. Critics love it for the in-jokes, maybe. But to be honest these in-jokes are just plain annoying and pointless.

I like films with a stage play feel when it's done right. Marriage Story has good rhythm and excellent performances but I feel the wit is missing. Adam Driver and Scarlett Johansson have both probably done their career best here. Ray Liotta and Laura Dern are both totally enjoyable. The intense dialogues and monologues are definitely great but they are just soooooo obviously vehicles for "outstanding performance of a lead role in drama".

To be honest, I doubt people will remember Marriage Story in 10 years. Maybe drama students will. As this film feels incredibly like a drama class exercise.

title: Could have done without the theater bits
review: Marriage Story has a lot going for it including a great cast - with the smaller roles being the most fun - like Alan Alda - but (spoiler here) the dialogue in the scene where the couple each lose it and scream at each other came across to me as too contrived, and not even believable "I wish you would die!" considering that the actual circumstances of the dissolving relationship are pretty tame. Another minor criticism is that for me, the injection of two theatre songs from Stephen Sondheim were off. This is a film, not a play. The scenes work in the sense that the husband and wife playing them are a stage actress and a stage director in the story, fine, but they fall flat for me, perhaps underlining the difference between what is good on the stage and what is good on the screen. Theatre goers may love those scenes but they yanked me right out of the film. All in all, enjoyable but not nearly great.

title: Modern Kramer against Kramer
review: It would be a perfect break up portrait if it hadn't been a modern copy of Kramer against Kramer. Too bad, the acting is great though.

title: Beautiful
review:
I have to start off by saying, whilst I am not the biggest fan of Baumbach's work, I am a massive fan of this movie. The movie simply follows a young married couple who live in New York as they go through the hardships of divorce.

Marriage Story has moments to make you laugh, to make you cry, to make you angry. You feel the emotions as the characters feel their emotions, all while never siding with either character. You feel like the child of a divorce being dragged from one side to the other, not knowing who to sympathise with and who your allegiance is drawn towards. This of course comes down to Baumbach's trademark realistic dialogue, and the performances of Adam Driver and Scarlett Johanson - they are both wonderfully superb! As a viewer you feel like a fly on the wall in the midst of family engagements and situations you feel like you shouldn't be watching as Baumbach manages to frame such an intimate setting.

Do not go into this movie expecting screaming and shouting, with temperatures constantly flaring - no this movie is not like that, in fact it delivers the same punches in a more subtle, quiet, moving manner. However, do go into this movie prepared for the best movie of 2019, as that is exactly what it is.

title: Is it boring and painful? yep. So it will probably get awards
review: I would not recommend this. Like MANCHESTER BY THE SEA, it is a long, painful slog through depression and misery. The Academies love this crap though so I'm sure it will get awards. Ugh - skip it!

title: Emotion Manipilation By Jackhammer Nightmare
review: I'd rather chew glass than watch this boring, pretentious, unlikable abomination again. Someone please return the two hours that was wrenched screaming from my life. But, if "The Shape of Water" can win an Oscar in today's wasteland, so probably will this pseudo-artistic snoozefest

title: Snooze Fest
review:
Maybe I didn't watch the whole thing, so I didn't like it. But this was really boring from the first 15-20 minutes. It had me teary eyed though, which is a good sign.

I thought Adam Driver was really good in it though. Scarlett Johansson I cannot stand sometimes. She's just ordinary, I don't know. I didn't like the Hollywood connection aspect of them both being in the business. I didn't like the arguing as husband and wife, and the marital challenges.

Not for me, might be for you.

4 stars

title: Masterpice
review: It was so good and it is very fantastic beacuse you have no words and dont now where to start it is just amazing Scarlett Johansson and Adam Driver is amazing as The leasing roles watch it but you have to be in to that kind of films to watch it

title: What a drag..
review: This movie itself is like a dreadful marriage: it drags on. Unwatchable with whining crying faces all the time. Big fan of Scarlett Johansson but couldn't look at her in this movie.

Dissapointing from Baumbach. It's all just a big ball of meh. The acting is great, the score doesnt make any sense considering the theme of the movie, supporting cast is bad, really awkward and cringy moments.

title: Boring
review: The Male lead is a good actor. The wife's lawyer is a great character. Other then that boring movie about divorce.

title: Not a fun watch. At all.
review:
Despite the constant barrage of films that are meant to excite, bewilder and entertain, there will always be an appetite for those that feel gritty, real and make you use your brain. This is the case with 2019's Netflix drama 'Marriage Story.'

In typical Noah Baumbach fashion, there's a lot to unpack here. 'Marriage' looks at the unraveling relationship between two middle class Hollywood types (Scarlett Johansson and Adam Driver) and how they deal with raising a son during a divorce. Unfortunately, this strikes very close to home for many, which is partly why it has found an audience. Unlike the personal dynamics at play here, the plot is relatively straightforward. Just like the flight path between New York and LA (and back) - a typical one for this industry - we alternate back-and-forth like a ping pong match, with Johansson and Driver trading barbs and trying to one up each other around every corner.

The real intention of 'Marriage' is to show off the acting capabilities of our leading and supporting cast. While Driver surprises, ScarJo comes off as forced and one-dimensional; the role of Nicole was written for someone who has much better range. And while Laura Dern dazzles as established divorce attorney Nora Fanshaw, she could be accused of rehashing her portrayal of the similarly cutthroat Renata Klein.

'Marriage Story' is a long, downward spiral that may make you think, but it also leaves you feeling pretty depressed. Some argue that it's an amazing team performance that should be celebrated, but it's just not a fun watch. At all.

title: Overrated garbage, Driver saves it with his performance
review: Not sure why this is nominated but I was just blown away at how good this looked on paper and how bad it was on film.. ouch

title: Overrated
review:
I think that movies should be rated not only for acting, but for storyline, too.

This movie is so boring, some scenes last ten or more minutes, which makes you do other things while watching it. The cast is great, direction, too, but plot is extremely uninspiring.

7/10, could've done better.

title: Very boring
review: I did not see a story to be honest. The actors are very good but the script and the idea are not interesting at all.

title: Sad, sad, sad...
review: Well, I sort of knew what I was getting myself into but I wanted to be surprised given the amazing actors. Yes, they are amazing but the story...just feels like an unnecessary film to watch.

title: Not friendly to UNMARRIED people
review: Unmarried people, Attentions! Stay away from it, and find another film to kill your time.

title: Nothing special
review:
Unlike the movie, I'll keep it short. A nice idea goes to waste by becoming a dragged out and overly dramatical story. Some plot points were presented in a strange way - for example, the very beginning when we find out they are separating and the end, when suddenly the divorce was settled a year ago. Lovely touch to include the songs from "Company" at the end, but it felt awkward and in no way did it contribute to the story.

Without the acting this movie would've been a complete failure. This way, I can't praise it more than being okay.

title: Not great not terrible
review:
Somewhere in the middle.
Certainly not a movie to be rated more than 8 stars in IMDB. Reading the various reviews you understand that the people who rated it 10 stars (simply ridiculous) is because they saw part of their lives in the movie. But is that enough for a good review?
Anyway.
Overall, the movie is quite realistic but also quite boring and pointless regarding the aftermath.

title: Powerful
review: This movie had some powerful scenes in it that portrays how ugly divorces can be especially when children are involved. The only time this movie isn't as good is when they have these weird artsy scenes and it just doesn't mesh with the trait of the movie.

title: Really?
review: Not a big Adam driver fan, so get ready. The one thing I took away from this was the utter banality of it. Driver's acting is always so-so but that was only part of it. It's a story that is always told to a new generation and then sold as better than sliced bread. His Oscar nom is on the order of Jonah what's his name in moneyball. Unbelievable.

review:
This movie got me kinda off. I havent read anything about the movie what so ever.

So at first i wasent sure if the movie was supposed to be filmed today or 30 years ago. The intro of the movie was weird, for some reason i got thrown off.

The main actor amd actress was good, even tho i never got the movie at all. Supporting roles was kinda "meh". Feels like i was at a theater.

title: Overrated
review: Was it the zoom in on the faces that drove people crazy? Honestly too mediocre.

title: A Marriage Story (if marriage is a contract and not a covenant)
review:
The beginning of "Marriage Story" begins with a wholesome timelapse of the couple's daily lives narrated by one another reading a letter of adoration about their spouse. However, the film takes a jarring comedic twist when it's revealed to the viewer this is just the beginning of the couple's separation. This clever opening compelled me to believe the film would be more than promising, but the next two hours would only disappoint. "Marriage Story" is hardly about the ups and downs of a broken family, but rather, a spectacle of downs alone where the complexity of love and heartache aren't challenging each other.

For a couple that could within themselves choose to see the good in their partner despite all the reasons corroding their marriage, it's hard to believe they're the same couple for the remainder of the film. The pair, Charlie (Adam Driver) and Nicole (Scarlett Johansson), are only ever able to overcome adversity scarcely when Nicole orders Charlie food and ties his shoe. This inability to rise above created very weak leads that coaxed distaste in the viewer for either one or both spouses. The two characters are overloaded with flaws that are grossly overlooked by their own judgement for the entire duration of the film, leaving them with only a single redeeming quality of wanting to do what's right (with not much motivation to do so). During their separation, neither experiences any genuine growth in their struggles outside of courtroom gain. Once the money and lawyers were out of the picture, the two are able to reconcile and be civil. Not because they worked on themselves, on the contrary, but because if they're not facing conflict that confronts their shortcomings, those shortcomings lie dormant until another issue arises. The film gives a false sense of growth, when in reality that growth was stumped by the characters' self-serving pride.

Despite being stagnant characters, Driver and Johansson have pivotal points of evoking emotion from the viewer, such as when the two have an argument in Charlie's new apartment and Charlie breaks down. Johanson plays a convincing mother and estranged wife and Driver truly embodies Charlie's emotions, making him seem more surreal, which made the film easier to digest. However, when Charlie sings "Being Alive" to seemingly vent his feelings in a format he best understands, it became less ingenuous. The longer the scene progressed, quickly it became more of a catalyst to fill the film's desire to be an artistic, Hollywood-esque film, such as La La Land. As for the divorce lawyers the film poked fun at, Alan Alda had by far one of the best deliveries in selling his role that outshined the more superficial portrayals by Laura Dern and Ray Liotta (which is largely due to their stifling characters).

Furthermore, the film hints at children being used as pawns in the courtroom, yet the film only allows room for Nicole and Charlie's child to become a convenient chest piece. Their child lacks depth or development, other than a "mommy's boy" attachment that causes a petty disparity between himself and his father. While Charlie and Nicole are trying to convince the viewer that their son comes first, they simultaneously are pushing for their own agendas without regard for their child, leaving their son neglected by both the couple and the script writer. For a character who is supposed to be so important to the parents, the character is treated as Waitress #2, and made ironically irrelevant to the story as a whole. Inadvertently, the boy becomes an accessory for the sake of the plot. Unfortunately, the poor development of his character made him quite unlikable, alongside his parent counterparts. In Charlie and Nicole's child, you'll find only the remnants of an idea rather than an individual, resulting in an unmemorable character whose name no one remembers (it's Henry). In this boy I see so many missed opportunities to explore the confusing pain of feeling divided between two people you love and the misguided guilt of driving them apart. In the end, you'll discover two parents who seem to care deeply and sacrificially for a child who's nothing more than a puppet who wishes he can be a boy.

Overall, the story wasn't strong. The characters danced around each other and had terrible communication just as the plot did with the viewer. "Marriage Story" is a sensualization of divorce written from a Hollywood-skewed perspective of marriage.

title: A wannabe Kramer vs. Kramer without the heart.
review:
Marriage Story (2019) isn't a movie about divorce so much as it is a movie about the east coast vs. the west coast. While I'll admit that there were some pretty good performances in this film (notably, Laura Dern was spectacular), there wasn't anything new here that other movies like Kramer vs. Kramer (1979) hadn't covered. Additionally, it was a bit difficult to separate the two leads (Scarlett Johannsson and Adam Driver) from their other famous movie roles, which made it difficult to commit to the premise fully. Plus, movies like Marriage Story are just uncomfortable looks into lives in shambles that probably hit too close to home for some people.

It's weird how so many successful elements didn't come together cohesively for me. Randy Newman's score sounded great, but it made the film sound more like Toy Story (1995) than Marriage Story. Likewise, with the famous acting talent present: they had exemplary performances, but it didn't seem to gel with the movie as a whole. I will concede that the opening scenes where the characters narrate what they love about their partner felt almost eerily familiar to my own life and its quirks, but perhaps that's just being able to codify the male and female conditions.

If I were to pinpoint one of the biggest things wrong with Marriage Story, it's the awkward moments. Most of these scenes seem to go on too long (like Adam Driver singing) or play to laughs or pity that made me cringe more than produce the desired effect. Additionally, one of the most shocking scenes was an incident near the end that felt like it would have had some lasting impact on the plot but was never mentioned again (despite its dire circumstances). I'm not going to spoil what that scene is, but you'll know it when you see it.

A wannabe Kramer vs. Kramer without the heart, I give Marriage Story 3.0 stars out of 5.

title: An unfair perspective from a man's point of view.
review:
This film just made me feel frustrated. I didn't like it, I didn't hate it. I just didn't get it. I felt like I wasn't the target audience even though I'm married and I have a young son so you'd think I'd be able to have some perspective. I could relate to some of the struggles, I could relate to some of the arguments. But mostly it just felt like a film written by a man, trying to make you feel sorry for the man.

And I did. I felt really sorry for Charlie! I wanted to see it from both sides but I don't think the writer really wanted that. The speech by Laura Dern about the idea of a perfect father only being a recent thing rang incredibly true. And the film only perpetuates this.

The film starts off beautifully with a list about what they each love about each other. It seems like it should be an amicable divorce. Then suddenly this crazy divorce lawyer is involved, Nicole turns into an absolute cow and Charlie is completely blindsided. I just didn't buy it. Moral of the story, all women want to do is take your children and steal your money in the process. Feel sorry for the poor man, he only had a little affair (which felt completely brushed over!) and now look what this awful woman is doing to destroy his life. It just made me really angry.

Great acting, horrible story.

title: Don't watch if you're depressed.
review:
I was feeling a bit low due to life stresses at work etc so needed a good movie to lift me up. Oh boy was Marriage Story the wrong choice.

I got about 28 minutes in before bailing to watch Don't mess With Cats.

Pretentious thespians with marriage problems. Looong monologues.

Laura Dern looks great though.

title: Feminist agenda with a thin slice of humanity for men.
review:
The movie has a very obvious feminist agenda.
Female main characters are so much stronger than male characters, that you can feel it is biased and forcefully fake.
So the idea of the movie WAS to be about broken marriages, but as the movie progresses you can sense the hate written towards men. The violence and weakness is always on the "male" side.
Don't really know why people think any of the actresses on this movie deserve to be nominated. The work done here is just "ok".
The movie would be so much better if the script was written not to portray women as superiors (because, in fact, they are not).

title: Sorry...I don't get it
review: How this movie got a nomination for best picture is beyond me. The only thing good is Adam Driver's acting. He is the only character worth any sympathy in the film. The rest just don't cut it in my opinion. And the story itself is horrible. One hint - the movie has an "R" rating only because when the characters had nothing else to say, the script had them throw in an f-bomb. Dern and Liotta are two dimensional stereotypes that play on the hackneyed joke of "we all hate lawyers." I didn't care about any character. Frankly, I found myself thinking the leads deserved to be miserable, because they were doing their best to make everyone around them miserable. So no, I don't get why or how this could be an Oscar worthy film.

title: Um
review: I'm giving up on becoming a fan of Noah Baumbach's films. I just don't really get the hype of this movie. It's not bad, but I didn't think it was that great. Kinda boring. Some scenes in particular the acting was really good, and some.. overacted and kinda corny. Not a fan of the dialogue. Idk, guess it's just not my taste.

title: Just not relatable
review: Overall, the characters just don't feel realistic and their situation seems to obscure/overdramatized to sympathize with. The leads have their moments, as does the strong supporting cast, but it feels too hard to get attached to the conflict when the story exists in some distorted reality. A charming movie, but not for everyone.

title: Again the trailer of a movie tricks me
review: Watched the trailer and really thought to give this movie a chance. Especially after seeing the reviews. Watched it and I was very dissapointed. The characters are dull, even annoying (the kid takes the icing on the cake), the story is weak and it feels a bit pretentious. On a plus aide, Alan Alda an Laura Dern did a good job.

title: So depressing
review: Well acted but excruciatingly boring and depressing. I've watched in 20 minute chunks as it's so hard to watch!

title: Disappointing
review:
Oy, what a disappointment is The Marriage Story! I expected some symmetric arch about people falling in love and losing each other, working through all the complexities of parenthood. Yet I found a one-dimensional law suit drama where a weak and egoistic Scarlett Johansson without personality ruins the life of an Adam Driver with a passion for his kid and the arts. The acting was fine but the writing was lazy. He is the only one who we really get to know, so she naturally comes across as a superficial evil coward. Their child is not really worth fighting over either. So many lost opportunities to make this movie worthwhile!

(And right now it scores even higher than the Irishman on IMDb ðŸ™„ðŸ™„ðŸ™„)

title: Indifference
review: I have to say, Noah Baumbach doesn't have me ever and Marriage Story is not different. Driver and Johansson and Dern and Liotta are great, especially Dern have some lines about women's duty that are stunning but the film lacks especially in the emotional part, too immature the reasons of her, it's ok that no communication and comprehension of the other destroy marriages but you cant be involve with her, and him is really annoying his passiveness with his marriage falling apart especially when the divorce broke you emotionally and financially as in this case

title: Heading off movie is stream over navigation.it is car off the film.it is film.
review: Value off the film is responsible in addition over value in addition over salute in terms off value. it is heading.

title: It felt that a lot of things weren't told...
review: I have to admit Scarlet's and charlie's acting were really good and the script itself is realistic but i think it wasn't executed in a proper order. It felt that directing was lost into action and discussions were mixed up and a lot of things weren't told like they were supposed to in an issue like this one... I understand though that a lot of people might relate and love this.

title: Mumblecore divorce story
review:
What makes us watch films? We want to be moved, scared, entertained, or simply engaged. At times we achieve catharsis, but in any case we always expect the filmmaker to have something new and interesting to say. Baumbach could have given us a new perspective on divorce or engaged us emotionally, especially given his personal experience, but he failed to dig deep enough.
The problem is that in trying to be somehow objective and presenting the story from both perspectives he fails to explore the inner workings of either character. We see what is happening to them but we cannot feel it. It's like listening to a guy you just met in a pub talking about his devastated love life. You can feel sorry for him, but after a while you just want to get back to your business. The most obvious comparison, Kramer vs Kramer was a bit of a melodrama, but it had something new to say, as it was questioning traditional parental roles. Bergman's Scenes from a Marriage gave us a precise dissection of the ego of its two protagonists and showed us new depths of human psyche. The war of the Roses was as far fetched as it was hilarious, but represented a cautionary tale for all those who do not choose to split up amicably. What did marriage story give us after two and a half long long hours?
We find out that divorcing is not pleasant and that divorce lawyers say nasty things.
The only reason we end up feeling sorry for the couple is that because of their expensive lawyers they are going broke. They are supposed to fight for their kid's custody, but we never really feel their love for the kid. We have to believe that they care because that's what's parents do, but from what I see I don't understand why adam driver simply didn't go back to his life in New York.
As per the acting, to me it looks like good but not outstanding improvisation. Adam driver could pull convincing facial expressions, but he seems to have lost his charm, while Scarlett Johansson tries so hard to deliver her monologues in an oscar worthy fashion but looks like she's acting all the time.
I really don't understand Hollywood's obsession with Baumbach and his partner Greta Gerwig. I find them so dull and boring.
Maybe you have to be a millennial to get their movies.

title: It's like an humorless Woody Allen movie.
review: It's like whoever wrote this thing. Decided to make a Woody movie, and left out any humor. There are a few unintentional scenes that are good for a chuckle. But its just a dismal movie about divorce. And the kid is irritating, but that's the writing. Up to you,but not really worth it.

title: Nothing special
review: Based on the reviews, I've expected very good movie. But, as million times before, reviews don't mean anything. Known story, hard, but seen thousand times before. You would not lose anything if you skip this movie.

title: Great acting horrible storyline
review: Directing this had to be hard but the story could have been better. Both parents only wanted for them selfs. Real parents don't fight to win for them selfs they fight for their child. Great acting by the main characters. It should be called the divorce story and everyone gets screwed.

title: Written by AI
review: Totally mindless. Every line gave me the feeling it was contrived. But it was well produced.

title: Watch A Separation instead
review: This movies was good but its story was basically like the Iranian Oscar winner, A Separation. It even ended like that, suddenly. It is possible that those living in US like it more but I am not of it so sure.

title: Black Widow meets Kylo Ren
review:
In the past few years, Netflix has been turning out some fine movies: Roma, The Irishman, and now Marriage Story. This latest one focuses on the effects that a divorce has on a family. Having never been through a divorce, I can't fully relate to it, but the strength of the characters and editing makes up for that. Scarlett Johansson and Adam Driver put all their effort into the roles of a separated husband and wife in a tense battle over their son. The movie's slow pace allows enough time to let the characters develop, and these are complex characters.

It might not be the greatest movie of all time, but it's an effective one, and I recommend it. The rest of the cast includes Julie Hagerty (Airplane!) and Wallace Shawn (My Dinner with Andre).

title: A potentially good mini-series wasted on a feature film
review:
Paradoxically, this movie is both too long and too short for its own good. The unfolding events and pacing lack any urgency from either character for the viewer to feel like any of what's happening actually needs to happen. At the same time, you wish you could see more into the lives and inner psyche of each character as they untangle themselves from their mutual past.

As this is hardly Baumbach's first attempt at storytelling on the subject, it pales to his early work and his joined efforts with actress, screenwriter and partner Gerta Gerwig.

title: One of the Best Films of 2019
review:
Sometimes movies get too much hype in award season, Noah Baumbach's Marriage Story was not one of them. If anything, this fantastic film should have taken home more trophies. It is a heavy hitter, and not for everyone. You definitely do need to be in the right mood to properly enjoy this one.

Without revealing too much I will just say that Adam Driver was fantastic. The guy can flat out act and Scarlett Johansson went to another level giving us an enthralling performance. Watching these two play off each other for two hours was a thing of cinematic beauty. Laura Dern's Oscar winning role was strong, as was Ray Liotta's lesser talked about turn as a lawyer.

Marriage Story will reel you in, churn you up and spit you back out. It's emotionally draining, and I mean that as a compliment in its highest form. It's a lesson in film making and story telling that others should take note of.

Marriage Story works on every level. Films like this only come by every few years and I highly recommend giving it a watch.

title: Powerful in some ways
review: It sure will make you feel. And anytime emotions come pouring off a screen as fluidly as it does in this film it's applaudable. It's a small focused story, a Marriage Story.

title: I felt that drama.
review: Scarlett Johansson's masterpiece acting. I was in the film every second. I felt that drama.

title: Good Movie
review: The magic of this film is how it doesn't demonize either side and shows how even under the best intentions that divorce, once in the legal process, creates enemies. Supremely acted with the right amount of sardonic humor to keep the drama from getting too unbearable. Every couple should watch this before getting married.

title: It has fantastic acting, but does it do anything else?
review: Hard to rate this one. On one side I liked it, it was entertaining and Adam Driver and Scarlett Johansson gave amazing performances, but the characters they play are really flawed. Some of their decisions lack further thinking. I do like Charlie more, but they both make terrible mistakes. I haven't heard of such divorce story in real life like ever, yet many say it's very realistic. Maybe it is realistic in USA, but in Europe it's not. IDK, I think this movie tries too hard to be sad and dramatic and lacks realistic character choices. Kramer vs Kramer has exact same plot yet is much more entertaining and sad and characters are much more believable.

title: Driver and Scarlett Shine
review: If you love god acting as much as I do, please see this movie. This is the kind of film they used to make in the 1970s that reflected true human emotion rather than comic book characters. The two leads deliver outstanding and raw performances that cause you to look at your own life and pull up deep emotions within yourself. It's a film that asks questions and doesn't necessarily provide answers, which is my favorite type of film. Great job Noah Burnbach!

title: Depressing, but realistic in a gut-wrenching fashion. And I have to side by Charlie.
review:
Look, I'm in quarantine and I had nothing better to do, so I sat through all the 'Best Picture' nominated films from this year's and singled out 'Marriage Story' and 'Two Popes' as the only two movies out of that bunch that I didn't watch. And Marriage Story was a far better movie to sit down and watch than Two Popes in my opinion.

The acting was just...phenomenal. Everyone in this movie acted their chops off in the most heartbreaking way they could. Henry's actor (Sorry, forgot his name) just made me depressed in a heartfelt way. He was the hardest to watch in every scene because I just hated to watch him favor his mom in front of his dad, be fought over like tug-a-war, and looking lonely when he was with his dad. I just couldn't... I simply just wanted to cry with his presence if you understand. I hated having Charlie just watching his relationship with his son fade. Adam Driver, like the kid, broke me. At the beginning I semi-sympathized with Scarlett Johansson's Nicole, but by the middle towards the end, the movie easily made me side with Charlie, even though he's no better.

I get that in divorces there's a bad side to each person that has to shine at some point. And at each point, I did come to hate both the leads because of actions they've done, but at the end, they're just humans. They made mistakes, and now one wants to move on understandably. But yet, for the one who wants cling onto a broken relationship and attempting to keep a legal fight going, I sympathized with him more because it was tough watching him hit rock bottom to fight for keeping some form of custody with his son, while simultaneously losing everything and his whole life just to maintain custody.

But Nicole also deserves to move on with her life without having Charlie's life consume hers.

It got ugly between both sides for sure, and this was hard to watch. But it was a very solid story that made all for a good film worth watching, with a great set of acting and direction.

My only complaints would be that but felt too repetitive and slow at times and some scenes felt out of place and random. The crossfading was just awkwardly edited to move on to other scene too. But those were my concerns.

In other words, a nice heartwrenchig tale. One for memory. Not perfect, but still not too forgettable.

Final rating 8.4/10

title: Jesus
review:
Marriage Story was easily my most anticipated film of the year and it met all of my expectations. Essentially every aspect of this was done perfectly. I don't think I've seen a film be this heartbreaking while also being pretty funny throughout. That alone probably makes this my favorite screenplay of the year.

The pacing in Marriage Story never seemed to drag throughout its runtime. The story feels so complete. It goes beyond what typical movies would go for, so the 2 hours feels full rather than bloated. Not to mention the fact that the characters, in true Baumbach form, actually feel real.

The acting was, of course, outstanding in this. While this isn't my favorite Scarlett Johansson performance, it's a pretty fantastic one at that. Both her & Adam Driver easily give some of the best performances of the year. Laura Dern, Ray Liotta & Alan Alda were great as well.

Behind the camera, Noah Baumbach isn't doing anything mind-blowing, but this movie never looks dull. It always looks beautiful, like a classic film in the making. The music from Randy Newman was also amazing.

I genuinely don't know how this could've been executed better. This could've been another forgetful Oscar bait movie. Instead, Noah Baumbach delivered a truly substantive film that people will talk about for a while.

title: Marriage is the grave of love.
review: The divorce tore apart a man's self-made world of happiness, and everything had to revolve around him in the past. As for his wife and children, he took it for granted that they were in their own way. So in the tearing of the divorce, he felt like he was unlucky, everyone was humiliating him and destroying him, and he had to deal with it awkwardly and failed. The subtle details of the relationship between the couple, once taken out into a weapon to attack each other, will be particularly hurtful. The two actors performed the complex emotion of love and hate.

title: A Love Story About Falling Out Of Love {criti-cally reviews}
review:
The biggest problem with great movies like Marriage is writing a review about it. The movie is about a couple who due to some differences want to go through a divorce. The movie is a close examination of the process of divorce and how messy it can get, changing people along the way until things get back to normal.

Marriage Story movies through multiple genres. It starts of a light, romantic comedy movie. We get to know the intricate details and a personality overview in the first 5 minutes of the film as both characters introduce each other. While we flash through important and daily situations, we hear Nicole (Scarlett Johansson) explain what she loves about her husband Charlie (Adam Driver). Charlie loves being a dad, and how it's almost annoying how much he loves it. He cries easily in movies. He's very competitive, undaunted and is very clear about what he wants. These are only a few things Nicole loves about him. After that, it's Charlie's turn to tell us what he loves about his wife Nicole. She's a great dancer - infectious. She's a mother who plays, really plays. She gives great presents. While we hear this couple recite what they've written down, we get to meet them post-break-up in a marriage mediator's office. This was part of an assignment, to fully understand why they got married in the first place. As we progress the movie knocks you out with a single blow as it switches genres, very smoothly in to a distressing drama.

Nicole, a former teen film star, wants to move back to Los Angeles with the couple's eight-year-old son, but Charlie, an up-and-coming theatre director wants to remain in New York. What follows then is an emotionally raw journey into growing up, while trying to figure out how to survive on your own. It wouldn't be a Baumbach movie without a man-child at the center of it. The filmmaker has spent his entire career profiling gifted men who are reluctant to grow up. In Marriage story, Driver plays the same - slightly immature, considerably self-involved, but also capable of decency and warmth. Baumbach's choice of letting Driver express himself fully as the lead role in the movie was a great decision. He is definitely the strongest of them all and delivers an Oscar worthy performance that is transformative, unseen and heartbreaking. It seems all the other actors are feeding off his energy and bringing their A-game to the movie. Scarlett. Johansen has never looked and acted better. From a caring mother, to a becoming a woman who won't let anything come in between her dreams now, Nicole's transformation couldn't have been portrayed better than anyone else. If Driver adds emotions to the movie with his heartbreaking performance, Johansen makes it move forward with her role as a women who still loves her husband, but wants different things for herself.

As the movie progresses, we can clearly see a change in Charlie and Nicole's relationship and personality, having to deal with the divorce. Where there once was an intimate and almost wordless understanding of each other, there is now bitterness and resentment, egged on by an almost clinical legal process. The film's most heartbreaking scenes are the ones in which Nicole inadvertently calls Charlie 'honey' in the middle of the most vicious arguments; or when she decides his food order for him during a tense meeting with their lawyers. "I will never stop loving him," she says in that opening voiceover. Which is true. Nicole had become into a woman who knows what she wants and isn't holding back anymore. The only thing she's holding back in front of Charlie - are tears. As if she doesn't want him to see how vulnerable and damaged she is by everything that's changing. "Love doesn't make sense", and no truer words have ever been spoken. Charlie on the other hand, who's always been confident and career driven, is now crumbling down, defeated and uncertain of the future.

On of the special features of the film is that it manages to get it right that both Charlie and Nicole had their faults and they also had been disrespected in different ways and so the movie conveys the idea that in these situations usually (not every time) the blame is on both, maybe not equally but everyone had his faults. While Nicole turns very sour in the process of the divorce such as going against their joint agreement to not involve lawyers and hiring the most ruthless person in the business, Nora Fanshaw (played by Laura Dern in a scene-stealing performance, giving some specular and hard-hitting truths about gender inequality). Meanwhile, Charlie is not only forced to pay a portion of Nora's fees, but is made to settle for the kindly Bert (Alan Alda), the only person who seems to have an idea of the human toll separations can take on couples. There are moments when you do feel sorry for Charlie and feel Nicole is being too ruthless. But then, when you look from Nicole's perspective, Charlie did have a relation once outside of their marriage which he clarifies with a remarkable line, "You shouldn't be upset that I ****** her, You should be upset that I had a laugh with her!". The fault lies in both, some more than the other, which is which is hard to tell.

The most important thing the script gets right is the theme of divorce. The movie very closely examines and critics on the entire system and process of divorce, its impact on kids, on how it makes the couples waste a lot of money but most importantly on the hate it creates. Indeed the protagonists starts the process with all the good intentions to split up peacefully but when the lawyers kicks in they found themselves in a fight they don't even want.

Baumbach emerges as true master of writing and directing in this movie. The script is very special and the little moments in the story develop the characters and reveal more about their nature. In a particular scene, Nicole commands her mother, who has an independent equation with Charlie, to not interact with him anymore. When he visits them in one scene, he knows exactly where the paper towels are, and which drawer the cutlery is in. Little moments such as this convey reams of information about the characters, whereas lesser filmmakers would've had to rely on pages of dialogue. In a particular scene of a courtroom battle With Charlie's new lawyer representing him after he fired Bert with Nora Fanshaw, we see both the characters just sitting quietly. It's like they weren't even mentioned in the script. It's the lawyers talking, delivering their dialogues and fighting it to, while both the characters are just quiet. But in the scene right before, they were fighting, and for the first time openly venting their anger out to each other. It was such a metaphorical moment that the protagonists, even though they seem calm and composed in the courtroom, have their inner turmoil's and anger and resentment towards each together which they are battling to and want to express.

Baumbach shoots pivotal moments in the film in long, unbroken takes, allowing life to just... unfold. There are no flashy cinematic techniques on display here, save for perhaps a couple of pointed visual metaphors like three bedroom doors closing on Charlie all at once. The actors are allowed to roam free; not at the mercy of traditional set-ups but with palpable confidence. They are fluid and the acting seems very natural. The characters seem very human, like someone you would know and real, feeling real emotions, which make you feel with them. The approach is almost like theatre. The set is a playground that Driver and Johansson can explore, as we watch, transfixed at the truth they are able to tap into, again and again and again. The camera doesn't confine them to tight spaces, but offers silent support as they amble in and out of rooms; as they walk through frames and stare directly into its depths. Baumbach makes all of it seem effortless, with unprecedented results. The way he gets his cast to deliver minutes of dialogue, while his Director of Photography, Robbie Ryan, zooms in and out, follows and swirls around them, to then play with shifting between different actor's facial expressions in silent moments, is utterly enchanting. The cherry on top is Randy Newman composing a score that is completely apt and masterful!

Overall, Marriage Story is a great movie, with excellent acting, a touching screenplay, an immersive direction and a delicate score. This is one of those movies that will get discussed in film school, years from now. It has everything to become an all time classic and will proudly get called one of the best films of the decade. It is so authentic that watching it occasionally feels like eavesdropping on a couple in their most vulnerable moments. A melancholic, heavy-hearted yet joyously bittersweet story about marriage and its unfortunate path to severance in order to find happiness. It is a love story about falling out of love which guarantees that no cheeks will be left dry.

title: A Need for Change.
review:
A bittersweet comedy about an marriage that is changing, but not ending. Actress, Nicole Barber (Scarlett Johansson) and husband and establish play director Charlie Barber (Adam Driver) work through a coast-to-coast divorce as Nicole pursues a Hollywood acting career. Marriage Story focuses on the struggle of changing dreams in life and in a marriage. Compromise is something not negotiable for this couple. The couple fights to find what is best for their son, Henry, as their lawyers fight to make Nicole and Charlie the enemy. Marriage Story, a Netflix original, gives the story of an established New York couple who works through marital problems in their own way.
The theme of this film is change. Change can come in many different forms and it can define someone's character by how they react to the world changing around them. In this film, Nicole and Charlie are going through a pretty serious divorce, a divorce that they did not see in their future. But, was necessary because according to Nicole, Charlie was a control freak of their marriage and never really listened to what Nicole wanted. There were many different factors that caused their divorce and the elements of the divorce causes some serious changes in this family of three. Change can be difficult for some, or a necessity for others, but how you react can often define who you are.
This film uses many techniques to make this film as great as it really is. The use of lighting and dialogue make this film. When in New York, the lighting of the film seems darker, giving that depressive East coast feel, while in California, everything is bright, representing new hope and happiness the sunshine gives. This is important because it shows the difference between the two cities and it also goes to Henry's emotions of his living situations. Henry was born in California, but grew up in New York. Once Nicole moved back out to California, Henry was happier, found more friends at school, and was around his cousins more than he was in New York. The lighting of these scenes help show Henry's happiness and how he thinks his life is better in California. Dialogue also helped created the emotion and intensity of the film. One scene that relied heavily on the use of good dialogue was the scene towards the end of the film where Nicole and Charlie were yelling at each other in Charlie's California apartment living room. They start off discussing what is best for Henry because during the divorce, they had moved away from the well-being of their child. This scene develops into a heated yelling match about all the things that they see wrong with each other and how their marriage did not work. Without the words said from both Charlie and Nicole, this scene would never have had the impact it did without the use of strong language and good use of dialogue. There were plenty of other film techniques used in this film, but lighting and dialogue were the most effective.
Marriage Story depicted a couple living the dream in New York until they were not anymore. Nicole and Charlie Barber were a successful, play producing couple, until Nicole wanted to change her career. Things went downhill when Charlie did not support her like she did for him all those year. This film was a story of change and how the characters responded to that change.
& Scene.

title: Marriage Story
review: Marriage Story is intimately directed and a heartbreaking dissection of one of life's most mentally-challenging affairs.

title: Good Film, But A Tad Long
review:
MARRIAGE STORY is a good, realistic story that keeps you intrigued from the beginning to end. The acting and writing are both excellent, and the directing is very good. Filmmaker Noah Baumbach has come a long way.

His earlier films were good and they've consistently been so since then. This is perhaps his best so far overall, though by only complaint is the length. Longer films are fine, but this feels just a tad too long for what it is. Still very good thought. Recommend.

title: Just OK.
review: Not sure why this is getting such great reviews. It's just OK. Not a compelling story in the least.

title: An Emotional Film About Complicated People
review:
First, the performances from Adam Driver and Scarlett Johansson are absolutely brilliant. They perfectly capture how people feel when they're going through a divorce, which is one of toughest things anyone could go through. You can see the pain in Driver and Johansson"s eyes, and when that pain comes to the surface, their performances take your breath away.

Second, Noah Baumbach did a brilliant job directing this. What makes the direction so brilliant is how restrained it is. There's a lot of scenes where the characters are just talking and expressing their emotions, and this movie allows them to do that in the most natural way possible.

Third, the main thing I liked about this movie is that it doesn't shy away from how complicated the characters are. This movie doesn't take sides and it shows the strengths and flaws with both characters. It's a story about how relationships can bring out the best in us but also the worst as well.

title: Emotional and honest in its affecting character portrayals, Marriage Story is a wonderfully written and acted look into marriage and divorce
review: Marriage Story is much more about the small actions that are indicative of character than big showy claims, and is so much more effective for it. Even as the story is about how a divorce happens, it's so emotionally charged because we grow to understand what their love was built on in the first place. Driver and Johansson are both absolutely exceptional, and I wouldn't mind at all if they won the two acting awards at the Oscars (especially if Nyong'o for Us and Pitt for Ad Astra don't get nominated, as it's looking). Johansson is particularly electric, showcasing her character's alternating anger and consideration. Baumbach's script is excellent, showing each character's side fairly and honestly, allowing us to empathize with both while never demonizing anyone. It's that honest, human heart of the movie that brings out the unexpectedly caring touches, like the shoe tie at the end, and the unexpected brutality, especially of one argument. It also makes plain the absurdity of the legal system, specifically in divorce, as it cost both of them boatloads of money while severely straining their relationship and not really getting either person what they wanted. In some ways, it feels like a faithful adaptation of a really well-written character driven contemporary fiction novel, where the characters are given space to be understood and where each interaction has such high emotional stakes. Extremely well made from start to finish, the ironically titled Marriage Story is intimate and deeply, honestly sad.

title: Extremely Bland
review:
Some questionable editing choices, none of the story was delivered visually, every single actor besides Adam Driver was boring as hell or is just a cartoonishly exaggerated archetype. The child playing the son was written like a teenage girl and seemed to always have the last word whether it fit his character or not, all the dialogue felt like it was better suited for a lifetime original movie and the film was nearly all dialogue.
This is an incredibly overrated title better suited for an off-Broadway play or basic cable and I am insulted it's up against the Irishman for best picture. Terrible movie, do not watch.

title: Opinions on 'A Marriage Story', Elites versus the Rest of Us
review:
There is a growing divide in our society between the cultural elitists and normal people. Its the difference between those whos world revolves around life in NYC and LA or Boston and San Francisco and those who live out their lives in ;flyover country'.

The wildly varying opinions on this film are perfect example. While then elites see this story as sad, but the 'new norm'. We commoners see a structural problem. We might ask who wrote these perverse laws that allow lawyers to make out like bandits while leaving their clients in debt and acrimonious. We even ask is the ScarJo character even had good reasons to want a divorce from a marriage that seems almost idyllic.

People in middle America tend to remain married and consider the best interests of their children and their family, its not always about me me me. People like the ScaJo character think they have something profound to give the world, more often than not, they don't.

The delusion of the elites was never more evident than the latest Academy Awards. Its astounding that this film was nominated and even won an award. They are so intellectually and culturally bankrupt that they are scaping the bottom of the barrel. 20 years ago, there would be so many great films that some all-time great films weren't even nominated. Now we get this. Wokeism and delusion rule the day. sad,

title: A decent movie, but from a male perspective, which decreases its appeal
review:
It is a decent movie, but its major flaw is that it still favors male perspective in the film - a husband who seems to be fighting for a custody over his son, while in reality he is simply fighting for his life not to change too much from what he got used to. Of course, its not admitted openly in the film, but if you watch it with a little bit of distance, you see it. The film would have been much better without a cheesy crying song that Driver sings in a bar at the end of the movie, complaining about his misfortune, and without pathetic reading of the long-forgotten sheet with his "good sides" put by his wife while they were still doing a marriage cancelling.

We have two people who irreversibly decided to divorce because it seems that both in terms of their private lives and professionally it works for both of them. The problem starts when (off course, like always in movies) the wife gets a famous female layer involved, who actually starts helping her put on the table what she actually wants, and not what her husband expects from her. The whole suspense is going about where the child will be based, NY (which suits the husband), or LA (which suits the wife). So a lot tears will be cried by Adam Driver just because Scarlet Johannson's character will insist on staying with a son in LA. This is obviously not a terrible decision because the kid loves LA, and the husband looks like a guy preoccupied by his work in NY anyway, and with no much patience for the kid, but the whole problem goes about the fact that this is something he did not expect: he believed that she would follow his ideas about the separation, and he is devastated when he discovers that she decided to push what is better for her.

The plot is subtly inviting us to sympathize with the husband, simply because he is a surprised party, he is someone who does not have good family network on his own, unlike his wife, someone who is not ready for change, etc, somebody who is pushed out as a secondary parent all of a sudden. On the other side, its clear that for 10 years he had it all on his side : a wife who adjusted her to him and to the role of homemaker, while he was the one in control. The film does leave us with a clear complaint about the fact that, as much as they are privileged in the marriage, men can be severely deprived of that privilege by the divorce. My problem with the movie is that its somehow, still invites the audience to judge this "change of heart" in the wife's decisions negatively. We still spend more time looking at Driver's shocked face just because he has to interrupt his directing job and pay lawyers, then the time we have an insight into what actually makes his wife wanting desperately to change her life. The point of criticism is still coming from the instance of white male patriarchy : like, white males complaining about why when they once form a family, it can't stay always the way they want. These are all the flaws of the movie, and with a little bit more work on the script and less "crying" over divorced male's tragedy, the film could have been really a masterpiece. But, now, its a kind of decent movie, but with already seen slippages.

title: Meh

Basically a very good quality TV movie.
