I enjoyed the excruciating black humour of the scene with the observer at the dad's apartment, but had to wait a long time for that gem of a moment, then sadly this was undone by the dreadful musical ending.

title: Scarlett Johanson was a mistake
review:
I liked the movie. I had seen the squid and the whale when it first came out and i think that Noah Baumbach revisits paralell stories.

However, I give it a 6 stars because watching Scarlett Johansson was a torture. She does not fit into the movie. She is not acting naturally - she never does. But one can tolerate her when she is the bimbo in a Hollywood action movie. Yet, in the occasions when we expect real acting, she is like this "vulgar, rude, grotesque" giant in the film, that disturbs you all the time somehow. She does not flow with the scenario, she cant develop a character, she cant show emotions.. She is always in the "look at me i am acting, i am doing you a favor, because i allow you to watch me, i am so great" mood.

I wish Greta Gerwig was in the movie. She is a delight to watch.

Better casting next time Noah.

title: Yet another American story
review: There are a few good scenes in this movie and Johansson's performance was not too bad, but in general everything felt kind of fake in it. The motives of the divorce feel totally faked and made up, the emotional turmoil of each party is unexplored (except in a few scenes), the focus is put instead on the legal matters, which feel casual and hollow. The worst part, however, was probably the kid, who acted anything but a normal school-going (6-7 year old?) kid. For instance he seemed to be completely ignorant of the fact that their parents were splitting up, he did not voice any concerns about it nor ask why this has to be so, he didn't understand he's father was hurt while lying on the kitchen floor, and he said that he liked the costume his mom bought better because it cost more... Seriously? In brief, the whole thing just felt fake.

title: 'An Uninspired Marriage Story'
review:
'Marriage Story' delivers a very simple premise in a very simple way. Therefore, it can only be effective in its performances, particularly Adam Driver's. The story focuses on what divorce inflicts upon people who'd once loved each other, yet lesser movies like Billy Crystal's 'Forget Paris' have a more interesting narrative to go along with this focus, and are more colourful in their approach. I commend the film's setting of 2019, as fewer directors today opt to set their films in the contemporary time period. The reason those warm terms "70's, 80's and 90's movies" exist is because those films were actually SET in their contemporary setting. Sure, 2019 is much blander than the previous decades mentioned, but it would be nice to one day look back on the 2010's the same way we look back on the 80's for instance, in film. The overall colours and look of the film (aspect ratio, palette) are nicely adjusted, although the film itself would benefit from a few more establishing shots of New York City, again linking back to the idea of contemporary. Show the 'One World Trade Center' just like older movies showed the 'Twin Towers' for instance, staples of New York City during different eras.

I often got distracted by Scarlett Johansson's obvious 'Oscar Bait' performance, while Adam Driver is always more grounded and realistic. What an actor, honestly, especially in those closing scenes. Laura Dern I suppose is intentionally unlikeable as the lawyer, and the awesome Ray Liotta could've had a few more comedic scenes to improve his character. Perhaps as a man myself, I found myself sympathising more with Adam Driver's 'Charlie's' point of view. Essentially, 'Nicole' (Johansson) wants a more prosperous career as a director, but 'Charlie' thinks too much of himself (as a director) to bother to notice. Whenever love is conflated with career, especially with themes of envy or jealousy, it's hard to connect to 'Nicole's' story emotionally. You just get the feeling that 'Nicole' is selfish and 'Charlie' just wants (rather understandably) to KEEP things the way they were since marriage. I mean, it was HIS job. HE got her into it. She agreed to marry him. Give it a few years and then end it to pursue more? What about commitment?

Their child 'Henry' is an insufferable, annoying and exceedingly unlikeable character. I hope this wasn't intentional, and the major drive of the story is the mother and father trying to figure out what's best for him, fighting in court for him, etc. It's revealed that he's eight years old, yet he acts five in every scene he's in. Which eight year old can't read the word 'time'? I know I wasn't like this at eight years of age... And maybe kids are just getting stupider these days, but hey, I was only born in 2001. Maybe the writer and director of this film, Noah Baumbach, just doesn't understand children in general. What he's directed here, is an occasionally moving but ultimately uninspired film, whose story is lead solely on the shoulders of very good performances. It will do its duty in picking up a few accolades during Awards Season...

title: Expertly acted, but to far from my life to hit home
review: This movie is for sure one of the best when it comes to acting and it's not surprising it several of it's actors was nominated for Oscars for their performances. However the "story" is too far detatched from my own life for this to hit home. I've never been married (and as such never divorced either), I don't have any kids and most of my imidiate family are still in their first marriages, including my paretns and grandparents. Still I know several firends who's parents are divorced, as well as some of my firends and some coussins, so I'm not virgin to the subject. Still, while I'm sure they all had their problems that they had to deal with (hence the divorce), I don''t know anyone who dragged lawyers into it or had to fight battles over custody of the kids or alomony and the like. Outwardly it all seems pretty smooth. It's either "Ok, we'll keep living close to eachother and as long as we are both clean and decent parents we split 50/50 whenever possible, and we each pay for the time the kid spends with us, not more, not less", or it's "We won't live close to eachother anymore, so let's decide one palce were the kids go to school and the other can see them on alternate weekends and longer periods over school breaks, in which case we'll work something out for how much the kids clothes and school material and toys etc. costs and split it". Maybe it's a cultural thing, since I live in Sweden, or maybe american movies/tv-shows just like to focus on the worst aspects of humanity and extream bad cases of divorce, or maybe everyone who I know who has been through one was just lucky exceptions, but this whole paying 100's of 1000's of dollars to bring in lawyers to sit in a room shouting at each other, not giving room for any acctual conversation to happen seems so surreal and unneccessary that I just can't find this movie very appealing. The court room scenes was also my least favorite parts of Kramer vs. Kramer, but at least that movie was maily about a father and son bonding, which still made it an overall positive experience.

title: Mediocre Marriage Story
review: This is a pretty mediocre movie about a less than interesting divorce. As is often the case when the director is also the writer, this movie suffers from a weak script and a dearth of strong tweaking. For a film about marriage - or is it about divorce - Marriage Story has little to say and offers little insight into marriages or troubled relationships. Scenes play out as if it is fascinating for the director watching behind the camera, but for the audience many scenes just seem to go on too long, or peter out, or need to be pumped up. Surely the biggest problem with the movie is that the motivation for this particular 'drama' is unclear. Here we have a youngish couple with a child, both with careers in the same business, who seem to be at a crisis in their marriage. But how we got there and the magnitude of that crisis is unclear and remains vague throughout the film. We see one stab at counselling and then bang it's off to melodrama-movie-style-divorce. For all the naturalness that is attempted here the behaviour and situations these folks find themselves in - and their subsequent behaviours - seem quite fake and unreal. Again this problem is due to a contrived script. The child custody element of this story (shades of Kramer v.s. Kramer) also doesn't work very well because at the heart of it is an immature, spoiled, selfish, neurotic and irritating child who seriously needs a firm hand and a haircut. And whereas the actors seem game, the scenes with the child actor feel stiff and constrained. The adult actors do a great job from Ray Liotta and Laura Dern and Alan Alda as the lawyers to Adam Driver as the husband. But Marriage Story really belongs to Scarlett Johansson who yells, laughs, cries, wipes away tears and basically owns this movie what there is of it.

title: A little bit too predictable
review:
Some spoilers alert...so beware.

I know it's not about having a twist at the end, with performances from almost all the cast being stellar who needs one. The directing is fantastic, love many of the scenes that were done a bit differently such as the carpark ticket scene. But somehow for this to be rated over on average as an 8 is a little high in my view.

The story is a little too predictable and the ending does not give you much satisfaction. It is littered with several liberals, let's say, propaganda which to me kind of takes away from the artistic side of the movie a little bit. But hey you can't watch a film these days without some political nuances or liberal or conservative propaganda being injected forcibly these days.

I love many sides of the movie but in the end it's just what you would expect from a drama about divorce with a kid stuck in the middle. It was quite a lot more focused on the wife's side of the story, making you think that there is a lesson to be learned intended to be for men more than for women. But there were moments when the film was trying to show the shortcomings of the wife too but did not go on bringing the balance required for this to be a complete story.

At the end part the ex-wife had found another man and the husband was made to look like the losing party by being single. The wife was nominated for an Emmy for her directing skills, so she is actually the one that is more talented than the husband, telling us all that she had the last laugh and once again another strong indication that it was the husband who is to be blamed and the one who screwed the marriage up by holding her back all this while and not helping her find her own thing in life other than being a supportive wife.

There was also a scene when the husband was seen to have badly cut himself but again I can't tell what it is about, there were scenes of this nature that you can't quite piece it together other than making the audience realise that this is all the husband wrongdoing.

However there were some attempts to show some balance. The wife was not all free of fault. During the scene where the big argument took place in the house, the film brought us some insights into the wife sort of neglecting the husband and also sucking the joy out of his life, indicating that women can take the fun out of everything but in the beginning she was described as being the fun one who loves to play all the time. The argument ended very abruptly with the husband screaming some very unkind words of wishing her to die. There was however no follow through on the mistakes or shortcoming of the wife in their marriage for this story to be balanced in the later part of the show. I get it that the world wants to think that men are often oblivious to his surroundings in a marriage and are not sensitive enough to their wives needs, so there is an element of feminism too which as I said takes away from the artistic side of the movie.

In the end I felt the ending was too compressed and rushed. 2/3rd of the movie could have been shortened for the ending to give the story a better balance of highlighting what both parties did wrong and how viewers of gender can learn from this story. I felt this movie should not try to masquerade as a marriage story as it takes two to tango. It should be 'An Ex-Wife Story' or something like that.

However from directing and acting, wow, just wow. Johansson was at another level altogether, a truly versatile artist. Apologies for the typos/grammar...had to share this views within short amount of available time.

title: Not for me
review:
I just want to say that from my perspective this movie was quite dull. I didn't felt anything watching it neather I enjoyed the realness of it.
I think it is just because I am too young (20+) to understand the characters more. Maybe If I will watch it in my 40s I will be able to be more emphatetic about the movie itself.
Anyways, great acting, especially from Scarlet Johanson and Laura Dern ( I kinda can't get over Adam-Kylo Ren sad teenager stuff).
I know this review is really personal, but just for the young people to know.

title: Belongs on the small screen
review:
From the beginning it's obvious Johansson was mis-cast. She's been great in a few things but looks, sounds and feels out of place here. It's hard to see there was any connection between Driver and herself - Driver does a pretty good job.

In general the movie meanders big-time and has the look and feel of a filmed stage play that is suited to the small screen where most people would've seen it.

Who ever thinks that Netflix movies shouldn't be included in the Oscars are probably right. They look terrible on the big screen (or on the small screen). They haven't so far worked on both.

title: Great performances, annoying movie
review:
If people can relate to this movies then perhaps they shouldn't ever start families.
Perhaps people are way too selfish nowadays that it's impossible to stand themselves, let alone leave with othes and make familes.

title: A brutally truthful depiction of divorce courts & misandry
review: I saw a comment on another platform where someone said they were rooting for both Charlie & Nicole. Are you kidding me??? To have such a view just goes to show the blatant level of entitlement & narcissism among certain women. No its never OK to destroy a man's life . Had the genders been reversed the reactions would have been off the chart.

title: Sorrentino with no house music.
review:
They love each other. It's hard to let go. But in the end Nicole gets everything she wants, find out that she can actually be a director and a successful actress, but screws up almost entirely the relationship with his husband. You could argue that every single thing does not really matter anymore to her and for her, as she states in the conversation with Nora, but that's her motivation. And the dialogue is so good in not really be able to go anywhere more specific. And the acting performed by S. Johansson and A. Driver is truly terrific and what really matters. It could be a Sorrentino kind of movie for what it matters, just without the house music and sheeps, because is all about the character as they reveal themselves to the audience. Nicole gets a positive arc while Charlie kinda gets over it after transforming himself into an insecure egoistic goofball. I don't like how this character is treated and the final scene, when Charlie gets to read Nicole's letter and gets a shoelace done, that's just WHAT IS THIS HOW YOU WANT TO END IT?
I'M so confused about this movie. I watched nearly three times and I still have mixed feelings. I hope A. Driver gets the Best Actor award.

title: Another overrated movie
review:
We decided to see the film especially upon positive reviews about adam driver's performance. Even some of the critics wrote they are curious about whether driver or phoenix will get the academy award. Yet expactation from a movie which is meant to portray a marriage/divorce is not met at all.

Travelling to Old memories? No. Psychological analysis of the spouses? No. Striking moments between these two? No. Emotional ups and downs of a relationship? No. Performances of johansson and driver are ok. That's it. A dull story on love/marriage/divorce whatsoever

title: If it were 30min shorter...
review: A good act, but the story got rather long... i reckon they could have cut 30minutes, and would have made a big change to the story. It potrays some honesty, but it would been nicer if some more positive things were added post divorce, as that is the general theme of the outcome. It was good to see Scarlett again!

title: What Is the Film's Point of View?
review:
"Maarriage Story," written and directed by Noah Baumbach, stirs a lot of thoughts for audiences. It gives a realistic depiction of a youngish couple with a child going through divorce. Adam Driver plays the husband Charlie, a rising-star, theater director in New York, and Scarlett Johansson plays his wife Nicole, a talented actress in his plays. Laura Dern plays Nicole's tough L.A. divorce lawyer. Released by Netflix, the movie is billed as a drama/comedy, but there is no comedy in this film's sad, realistic portrayal of two decent persons' drifting apart, with one of them deciding to leave. After the separation, horrendous acrimony slowly builds until a final, emotional blow-up shatters everyone-the couple and the audience.

Whose point of view tells this story? The man's or the woman's? Or, was the take-away for a man watching this film different from the take-away for a woman? Having thoroughly experienced the couple's feelings, I, a woman, left the theater wondering if a man had experienced the characters' heartbreak differently from me. I felt it must be so, for the film's point of view lacked clarity.

I called a friend, a male and a millennial psychologist, and indeed his take-away was wholly different from mine. While I identified and sympathized with Nicole's stunted potential in a marriage where she served her rising-star husband, who loved her and their family life, but had no true interest in her "being," who she was, as his passion and focus were totally on himself and his work and ambition. Everything else was rote for him and done according to the book of what was right and currently "enlightened," such as how to be a good father, a considerate household partner, and a good, fair, and beloved director to his troupe.

When, as happens in long marriages, Nicole lost interest in sex, Charlie found sex with the stage manager of his company. No, he didn't love her, he just needed that kind of intimacy and ego-gratification. He is god in his world. But the affair isn't why Nicole leaves. She leaves because at age 40ish, she realizes she isn't fulfilling her own life, her own gifts, her own passion, and she will never be able to if she stays with Charlie to serve his life and his success, which includes receiving a MacArthur grant for $600,000 to further advance his talent. Moreover, his new play is going to Broadway. His power and recognition are only going to keep growing while she stays as she is-his dependable wife, his actress in second place, his competent family partner, his solace and safety when home in the nest she provides.

As in all marriages that begin in the mid-twenties, the partners evolve with time and their risk of not evolving together is high. Charlie and Nicole clearly love and care about each other, but the marriage is over for Nicole if she wants to live, if she wants an authentic, fulfilling life. She returns to her mother's home in L.A. when a pilot TV series offers her a role. She takes their son Henry along. It's not certain the show will take-off, so the trip is presented as short-term to see what happens. Once there, however, life feels so good to Nicole-her true identity is able to emerge, not only as an actress free from the shadow of her husband's greatness, but also as a future director herself, which is her dream. Henry also loves living in L.A. with Nicole's active, extended family life that includes cousins. The only problem is, Charlie's life is in New York, so that his career and ambition become bombed by Nicole's decision to remain in L.A. when the pilot succeeds. But it's not just the pilot that makes her stay. It's her good feelings about herself, about having a meaningful life, her right just as much as his. In L.A., she's not Charlie's appendage anymore, which was fine in her twenties when she worshiped him and came under his wing, but it's not fine now in her maturity. She has her own developed talent, equal to his when freed from its cage.

My male friend's take-away was different. He saw Charlie as the victim of Nicole's manipulations. She left New York knowing her L.A. stint was going to be permanent. She tricked him, and now has the child legally in L.A. causing a custody suit. Her character was shallow while his was deep. Not only that, but Adam Driver was a far better actor than Scarlett Johansson. And Nora, the aggressive L.A. lawyer, was creepy, hideous-he shuddered just remembering her.

I want to pause here and say that Nora, portrayed as L.A.'s toughest, man-gouging divorce lawyer for women, also affected me as a female viewer. She's groomed pejoratively: slinky, skin-revealing clothes , long blond hair incongruous with her aging face, and a fake way of communicating with her new client, all saccharine in order to win her business. Why was Nora presented this way? Perhaps to mock L.A./Hollywood culture when it comes to divorce, for Charlie's L.A. male lawyer is even worse. These characters are driven by money and how much you can get from your future ex-spouse; no concern for damage done to children and the parents in such an antagonistic, bitter, and volatile tug of war. It's crass and tragic.

But there's more to consider. Everything that spouts from Nora's smart, fighter lips about the double standard is true. Who is listening to her? Perhaps some members of the female audience. I heard her and as a result, overlooked her unappealing traits because she spoke the truth about male-female relationships and how society condones men and condemns women in the same situation. My male friend couldn't tolerate her, and because of her money-grasping and exterior traits, he felt even more that Nicole was a conniving manipulator and Charlie a victim. Again, the film's point of view comes up. Was everything Nicole said to Charlie about her deepest feelings and why she was leaving, and Nora's pronouncements about the double standard, part of the script for the truth they told or part of the script to mock women in favor of Charlie the battered hero?

It would be interesting to set up a poll to compare the male and female responses to this movie-and I welcome hearing from you. The film ends nicely, because Nicole and Charlie are able to go back to their original, honest and caring roots and dump the lawyers in their divorce. And Charlie accepts the reality that Nicole is not coming back and figures out a way to make fruitful changes in his professional life in order to be near his son. But what is the film's point of view about that, about Charlie making changes to accommodate the divorce? My point of view is: good solution. My friend's point of view might be: she forced him to wreck his career, give up his New York life and passion. Nora the lawyer might say: This film perpetuates the way society has always viewed women as demons; it upholds the superior integrity and value of men. And the film? We don't leave the theater knowing the film's point of view, but my closest guess is: Charlie's beleaguered treatment deserves our support. Hopefully it's a wrong guess.

title: Just... meh
review: I expected a lot from this after seeing the rating/reviews. I feel it is highly overrated. Great acting, but that is all.

title: Noah Baumbach gave me a bumache
review:
Probably an accurate depiction of divorce, overrated as a movie.

CJR

title: not that interesting
review:
About halfway through Marriage Story I turned to my girlfriend and said, "you know, I totally don't care about these people or what happens to them." And she said "me too!" And I said, "and you're friend was right when she said this was just the problems of privileged white people," and she said "totally!" And I said, "you want to bag it, or keep going?" and she said, "let's just stop."

I liked the first scene, the acting was good, but these are uninteresting people in a depressing situation and while I appreciate the rather nuanced approach to the subject matter, I can think of no earthly reason to care if either of them lives or dies.

title: 8 STARS NO WAY
review: Poor scenario,average acting. I couldn't stand to see more than 3/4 of the full movie.

title: Unrealistic
review: I found this incredibly unrealistic. The characters are really weird and have no chemistry. The acting wasn't at all what I would have expected. Some of the dialogue felt so fake and overdone. I tried but I couldn't make it all the way through.

title: Likeable, extremely selfish and self absorbed couple screw up their kid for life
review: This is the most pointless divorce story I can recall ever seeing in a movie. Neither of them should get the kid, he should be in the full-time custody of the grandmother.

title: Weak story line, not great acting eirther
review: I love cinema and I love watching movies of all genres and from all over the world. I honestly cannot believe this film is critically acclaimed! The story line is not just weak, it's very weak and the film is quite simply boring. The acing wasn't great either and at times felt too faked, rather than genuine. I haven't gone through a divorce but this is not be a reason for me not liking the film if it's well done; this one simply isn't.

title: Adam Driver is amazing, it's just a really heavy film to watch
review: What a waste of talent in Star Wars with Adam Driver, because man does he really shine in this. This movie is very hard to watch, it's extremely hard to watch especially when you have been a victim of verbal abuse, but I did make it all the way through and while it wasn't that great, and my opinion I do really believe that Adam Driver deserves awards for this performance because man, he is good.

title: What made critics likeable about this film!!
review: Though i liked the The squid and the whale, Marriage story does not deserve to be nominated for the best film category for Golden Globes, Bafta and Academy awards. Overall, it is a good film but that's it. The rating should be between 6 and 7. If you'd like to watch sth similar to this as masterpiece, i'd recommend a Seperation by Asghar Farhadi; Who's afraid of Virginia Woolf by Mike Nichols or Custody by Xavier Legrand.

title: Overrated
review: It's a divorce story..........Two people who love each other getting divorce because of their egoistic characters......The most important part of a marriage is compromise. Better go and watch "Praktan" way better movie than this on this topic.

title: Not as great as anticipated
review: Very slow, the only scene that got anything out of me is towards the end when the 2 main characters have the huge fight and say all the nasty things to each other that you're not supposed to say when trying to take the high road, but you can't hold it in anymore. One great scene, and the rest very plodding, depressing and just meh. I mean, divorce is supposed to be depressing, but these two married people are so underwhelming personality-wise, it's hard to care about either of them. We do get a fairly good education on slimy LA lawyers and how hypocritical they are. It's all kiss-kiss, hug-hug for appearances, but when it's time for the big show and screwing people over to get everything at any cost, they are snakes! Yes, all the performances are good, but the material is nothing new or ground breaking. Based on all the hoopla of the main character's performances, I was expecting to be blown away. Instead, I was waiting endlessly for something epic to happen, but instead, it was another movie about getting divorced, which we've all seen already in one form or another.

title: Mediocre flick with terrific acting
review:
The acting was terrific, but this writer/director...ugh!

I do not understand why he gets so many accolades. The guy is clearly a misogynistic self-absorbed doofus. I feel sorry for his current wife because someday she, too, will undoubtedly find herself portrayed "fairly" with all her brilliant language and dirty laundry displayed publicly and for his profit, because, of course, it's all for him to show how brainy he is that he can attract such women and how deep he is that he manages to cull their best lines for himself because, of course, their lines are all intended for his work. Meanwhile, the male character will be whitewashed into this nice guy where bad things just happen to him, at the hands of a woman, with zero reflection or accountability for his own part in the relationship. Again, ugh.

By the way, this was done much better in Kramer v. Kramer, a film where the adults actually grew from self-reflection.

title: Should have been called Divorce Story
review: I wouldn't have watched it....... Like I need to see people being selfish, it's everpresent anyways.

title: An American Separation - inspired from A Separation but lost the humanity
review:
In short, watch A Separation (Jodaeiye Nader az Simin) if you want a similar story, but with a human touch. Apart for the long list of cliches, I think Marriage Story does a great injustice to children. In a divorce, the children are always the ones paying for their parents choices, they are always missing the happy family, they care for their parents and always blaming themselves for the separation. The films fails to show any real emotion of the child, as the authors were trying to feel divorced parents feel good about their children.

The only real thing to me were the actors playing the lawyers: Laura Dern, Ray Liotta and Alan Alda. All three had excellent performances, that were not wasted by the script as it happened with the two main characters. The impact of the formal approach on divorcing people's feelings and actions is the only area were this film comes close to A Separation, excepting the unrealistic lack of resentment for the terrible things done to each other by the main characters. But who can complain about realism from a film where the parents have still plenty of energy and time to spend with the child after buying two new houses in LA, without selling the old one from NY, paying the top lawyers and a lot of travel between the west coast and east coast, all while also being successful at work?

So, if you want feeling and a film that deserved its Oscar, watch A Separation. If you don't want the effort to think and to read subtitles, then watch this as at least the acting is better than a telenovela, but don't expect a better script.

title: Blablabla-Land
review:
Rather uninteresting & hugely overrated. An egotistic woman gets the better of her husband with the help of the caricature of an L.A. divorce lawyer.
Great acting, though, especially by Adam Driver. If you don't totally dig Scarlett Johannson, stay away from this movie.

title: Pretty weak
review: The movie is pretty mediocre. Woody Allen's movies are so much better in describing the divorce. The only good thing is that this movie is a pretty realistic depiction of divorce in America. A woman decided to destroy her family and her husband because she "wants different life". Legal system/family courts are completely female centered (alone Duluth model is horrific for males - look it up if you don't know what it is).

title: Why Does a rip-off of Kramer. VS kramer getting so much publicity.
review: Can't think of anything new in this picture, if it wins the oscar it will be a disappointment for the deserving movies.

title: Engaging.
review: The title may seem ironic; 'Marriage Story' is, after all, about a divorce. However as much as it's about the end of a marriage, it's the little moments of love and affection that Baumbach really chooses to focus on. It's an engaging character study and nuanced look at the legal system that is extremely well written and features some of the best performances of the year. Seriously, Johansson and Driver are at the top of their games here, injecting life into their characters in even the quietest of moments. That's where the film really succeeds, too. For a story about a divorce, there are less arguments than you'd expect. Of course, they do happen and are expertly done (one scene in particular is destined to become a classic and is sure to be studied as a masterclass in writing and acting), but it's the restrained, subtler scenes that really create the most emotion, and highlight the strength of the piece. While it's obviously sad and emotionally affecting in that regard, it's also surprisingly funny. Even though it's never hilarious, there's a sense of humour injected into nearly every scene. This is mainly due to how realistically the piece is written, as the humour comes from common, everyday interactions more than jokes. Again, the simple fact that this tone works highlights just how strong the writing is. One of its biggest missteps, however, is its focus on Driver's character, Charlie. After an introduction to both parties, the film begins with a heavy focus on Johansson's character Nicole, then shifts to Charlie's perspective. The problem is that from there onwards the audience sees things very much from Charlie's perspective, even if the flick ensures that neither Charlie or Nicole are seen as a 'villain'. Because it initially establishes itself as a two-sided piece, it does feel a bit limiting that Charlie is undeniably the protagonist. That's not to say that Nicole isn't a great character, however. Whenever she is on screen, Johansson and the writing are great. We do primarily see her from Charlie's perspective, though, which obviously limits things. Luckily, this isn't enough of an issue to ruin the film by any means, and it's something that's more of a problem upon reflection rather than when actually watching it. Randy Newman's score is a little bit of a problem, too. While the music is in itself great, it is very similar to Newman's 'Toy Story 3' (2010) score, so whenever it plays it is simply reminiscent of that film rather than serving to enhance this one. That's a very minor issue, though, and likely something that won't affect most viewers. Overall, 'Marriage Story' is engaging throughout with a great screenplay and subtlety gripping performances. It's certainly one of the years' better films and it's a shame that most people will only be able to see it on the small screen. 7/10

title: Overrated
review: Rich people's problems. Nice acting but really boring story.

title: Boring
review: One of those movies you'd play in the background while reading a book.

title: Narcissist Story
review: A depressing store about self absorbed adults who shouldn't have kids.

title: Sooooo overrated
review:
The only reason that I give this movie 4 is just acting. In real life, people are divorcing but most of them are not like this. Some women getting killed after divorce, some people left in streets with nothing, some people losing their kid etc. BUT in Marriage Story, Charlie has enough money, Nicole is moving a luxury house in LA and doing stuff about acting. Such as Charlie is going back to NY but doesn't care his son. Both sides are too selfish to think their son.
This is just a trash movie but nothing more as a drama.

review:
Okay story
Poor acting
The only thing I truly appreciate is the way this movie was filmed and the beautiful scenes

title: Dark Phoenix please call me please please call me I call
review: Avengers game of the day wwywywywywy was the day I was going home and I had a great day and I had a ww

title: Managed to have my attention only for 40 minutes.
review:
Not my cup of tea.
Good performances by the cast, but the story just doesn't resonate with me. There was no connection at an emotional level. Very, very dry.

title: Not getting the hype
review:
This felt contrived to me.

My guess is others see what they want. They're filling in missing blanks with their own experiences and projecting that into the movie. But, what's actually in the movie is not as deep or interesting as they're making it.

This is a talk instead of show movie. We never really see what it was like, we only hear the stories after and the portraits of before (the letters) don't match up to the actions of the characters later.

title: Did I miss something?
review:
I watched this film based on all the outstanding reviews and the high average rating of 8,0 and have to admit I was a quite disappointed.

Many lengthy and unnecessarily long winded parts combined with a rather plain storyline ruined my expectations.

Although Johanson and Driver are generally two great actors, they failed to persuade me in this one ...

Would not recommend watching the movie.

title: Straw Man Story
review:
This movie is so contrived & false that it's infuriating. Why did they put themselves & their child through all this? Because of some flimsy stubborn competitiveness established in the beginning? I'm not buying it. And even so, that just makes me loathe these characters. It even goes so far as to lay on a disingenuous feminist element that is completely off base & laughable for no other reason I can imagine than that Baumbach wanted pander to the current political climate. Laura Dern's spiel on women's disadvantages in society do not apply to the court system when deliberating custody. Conversely, it's the man rather who's dealt the disadvantage in this case(Driver even had to pay for a third of Scarlett's legal costs!). The woman is favored in such a circumstance for a reason the Liotta character explicitly brought up earlier on in the film. So, now the film contradicts itself too... . I can 't speak for others(clearly to some out there there's resonance here), but as a child who has virtually known divorce all his life, who cannot even remember when his parents were ever together, I could not get over how phony this all felt. As a human being I could not get over how infuriating this all felt(& not the way it was intended). Unfortunately, not even the acting could redeem it for me in any way. In fact, the acting was so good at times that my disgust for the characters would momentarily slip off onto the actors. I found this to be just a bunch of noise & emotions around nothing, wherein they waste their money & potential on divorce proceedings that neither one of them wanted, but sustained anyways out of a sick power game; meanwhile, the world's got real problems going on...In other words, there is no real problem here. Just middle-upper class, self-indulgent, first-world idiots with maniacal egos stirring one up & then acting like nothing happened because Driver needs his shoe tied...

If Baumbach needs a solid story to film he should consider reading some novels & optioning something because clearly he is just forcing something here out of what may be a drought of anything more substantial to say. It's a movie about people who have the resources to be relatively happy, but who create a problem for themselves & come out the other end with nothing--like nothing at all had happened. It's empty. Nobody likes a straw man argument. Well, ladies & gentleman, this is nothing more than a straw man story...

title: Nothing special
review: Too Much noise for this movie. I could hardly have emotions while watching it. Bad acting and Laura Dern wining an oscar for what? For wearing high Louis Vutton heels ? Waste of time.

title: Worse Than Expected
review: The story and casting are great. I felt all the emotions about divorce while watching. But what about action? It is predictable and not gripping.

title: Wrong title, Wrong message - Should have been called Divorce story
review:
This is an English Hollywood film starring Adam Driver and Scarlett Johansson.

I think the film has the wrong title. It should be "Divorce Story".

And the him has a totally wrong message: It makes you feel totally sorry for the guy and how he gets manipulated and loses everything, his child and growing career owing to the divorce proceedings.

And on the other hand, his wife and her lawyer manipulate the whole situation to their advantage causing him to lose it all.

The film should have had an even message to be fair.

title: Not my kind of movie
review: I gave the movie a try. I watched it for half an hour. It is slow paced, narrative and feels like watching someone's life. I was not able to connect with the characters or narrative. Maybe I am watching it with a bad understanding?

title: I wonder
review:
The movie just left me wondering: What if the roles of the characters were inverted (him/her)? That man would not stand a chance.
Tragic anyway.

title: Great direction
review: Tasteful scene directing, good dialogs and acting, nice photography and theatrical indie style. Also the point of view about the divorce is interesting and has some depth. Overall everything is positve but it needs something more to get a higher score, the whole movie needs more meaning and message to stand out.

title: Marriage Story
review: Near the end of the film, Nicole, who has a new love, hears that Charlie is about to move to Los Angeles to settle down. When she sees each other, she feels speechless. Then she chokes a little. This scene should be the most delicate and powerful scene in the whole film. It tells two painful things respectively: when a person has stopped expecting all the time, what she pursues has been achieved unexpectedly, and when a person finally learns to sacrifice himself for her, the person he wants to sacrifice for has gone. The movie gradually reveals the spiritual world of both parties in the conversation over and over again. How much concession the woman has in the marriage is how vicious it is in the divorce, and how selfish the man is in the marriage is how overwhelmed he is in the divorce. By the end, no matter which side of the audience is more inclined to divorce, they will not feel that the other side is making trouble or even empathizing with the other side.

title: Marriage Story
review: However much we may not want to admit this fact, no relationship is free from power

title: Too Long Too Slow
review: I think f I watched 3*15 minutes parts from the beginning, the middle and the end of this movie, it will not affect my thoughts. Their acting skills are very high at some points but not necessary to show this much wtihout a powerfull story.

title: boring 😐
review: How do you manage to make a movie about divorce so boring. watching my own parents getting divorce would be more entertaining. i hated this. i hate men

title: Nora (Laura Dern) and Nicole (Scarlett Johansson)
review:
Favorite scene with

Nora (Laura Dern) - The first day in Court.

Nicole (Scarlett Johansson) - Violently fighting with Charlie.

title: Very pedestrian
review: Watching this movie was like wading through treacle. Despite the best efforts of Adam Driver I kept clock watching. I think Scarlett Johanssen was miscast in this role and Laura Dern seems to play the same 'character' in just about everything she's been in, so no surprises there. Just disappointing. The moral of the story ....when it comes to divorce, the Lawyers are the only winners.

title: Yet more Hollywood navel staring
review:
Enough people have called this "Divorce story" to make that point.

I guess the popularity of the movie comes from watching our fantasy action stars actually act.

That being said, Alan Alda proved, once again, how to make acting look effortless and real. Instead of "Watch me act!"

Can Hollywood PLEASE stop writing movies about Hollywood and spoiled actors/directors? Do you not realize that there are actually people with careers & lives off the stage and screen? Or is that now the only way you can win Oscars?

Like others, I was surprised at how one-dimensional this was. And how poorly written some scenes were.

Also, if you are going to pay homage to another movie in your soapbox rant (Kramer vs Kramer), it's OK to mention it. This was supposed to be real life. I'm looking at you Nora/Laura Dern.

Instead of watching this movie, read "State of the Union" by Nick Hornby. That actually *could* be titled "Marriage Story." And is far more nuanced.

title: I am sorry watch this movie.
review: I have lost my time watching this movie. It was promising. It was nominated to important awards, it won some of them. There is nothing to watch except perfect actings.

title: For me, it was Depressing, Sad and at times Boring; Would not recommend it
review:
I'll be totally honest with you.

Admitting that the performances of all actors were all great, I must say that the story and the script were perfectly made to depress you.

Its a painful drama that I did not enjoy, would not watch again and would not recommend to anyone who wants to go to a cinema to be entertain and inspired.

It was nice was seeing Alan Alda and Ray Liotta adding to the film. It was fun to see the court room exchange between Liotta and Dern.

Also okay was the war of words at Adam's apartment between Adam and Scarlett. That was some acting that I enjoyed.

Scarlett was cute while dancing and singing with her mom and sister, telling us that her return to LA was going full steam ahead.

In addition, some lines were fantastic like "I need my own a**hole." Or this one:

"The thought of having sex with you makes me want to peel my skin off"

hahaha

But that was it. Nothing else there fore me

Divorces are all painful. then a movie about a divorce you can imagine what you will get for your buck.

Unless you love divorces and drama and tears and devastation and the breaking of a marriage, its likely you'd leave the cinema quiet, silent and wanting someone to cheer you.

I guess, some people love drama and tears. Others like entertaining feeling-good flicks. I belong to the second group. Did not enjoy Marriage Story.

But don't get me wrong, I love the actors and love their work and their nominations are well deserved. I just do not like the movie because do not like the story nor the script... at all. But that is just me, and this was my honest, humble opinion.

title: Sad but unfortunately honest
review: The acting in this movie is actually pretty good. The story is honest. Overall, it is a very disappointing story. And for some of us, who have lived this, it hits close to home.

title: "I want..., an entirely different kind of life."
review:
This is a tough movie to watch if you've been divorced or are thinking about it. And even if you're happily married for that matter. At the same time, the story seems realistic enough that you could picture two people going through this experience with all of it's emotional highs and lows. As a couple, I couldn't actually relate to Scarlett Johansson and Adam Driver as characters married to each other. Driver in particular doesn't strike me as the leading man type, but that might have been for the better as the reasons they got married in the first place were eloquently spelled out in the pair's individual letters to each other. My first instinct about Nicole Barber (Johansson) was that she was entirely non-cooperative with the marriage counselor who was trying to help them understand why they fell in love with each other. Writing out their feelings seemed like a worthwhile project, but for Nicole not to share the information seemed quite unreasonable. As the story progresses however, we learn that the give and take in the marriage was pretty much one sided with Nicole doing all the giving, and Charlie (Driver) doing all the taking.

Enter the divorce attorneys and the situation takes on a grim aspect. Alan Alda's brief stint as Charlie's lawyer was quite comical actually; his unintentional (or maybe intentional) way of double talking was quite amusing and had a way of driving Charlie batty. The eventual sparring between Nora Fanshaw (Laura Dern) and Jay Marotta (Ray Liotta) managed to negate the intended peaceful resolution to the divorce which had been premised by the Barbers when they first began thinking about it. As for that social worker (Martha Kelly) who called on Charlie and son Henry (Azhy Robertson), well, she looked like she could have used a good intervention herself.

The sad thing for the Barbers after the fact is that the marriage could probably have been saved had they allowed themselves the time and distance to come to terms with their situation. Instead, there was no happy ending here in the traditional sense, Nicole and Charlie each went their own way with no sense of fulfillment or closure for either one of them. I could have done without that theatrically inspired ending with Charlie singing to his friends at the bar back in New York. It wasn't particularly entertaining, and if you noticed, no one clapped their approval. Which is kind of the way the story leaves you feeling as a whole.

title: Regular
review: Not very good, too much romance and bad drama. If u don't like romance, u won't like this. For me, not an option to the Oscars.

title: Sooooooooooo loooooooooooong
review: Great acting, but really long to sit through this kind of movie for 2 hours.

title: Overrated
review: While the acting was good, the story was depressing and not real in my opinion. Too much dramatic dialogue, not at all like normal conversation, more like words from a play. The couple had a decent relationship and claimed to want an amicable divorce but Scarlett's character went way off track. Again it wasn't believable, it was over dramatized. Her character didn't even appear to have the best interest of the child. And, really, that kid was too old to behave the way he did. I divorced a mean drunk, and we were way more civil than these two, well mostly her. The only winners were the attorneys.

title: Yawn
review:
Tedious, talky flashback to the absurdist dramas of the 1960s. Sort of a 21st Century Kramer Vs. Kramer. Thankfully, lead male character Charlie (Adam Driver) apparently has deep pockets, despite being a Broadway director director and protesting to the contrary, as he is able to two attorney's retainers ($35,000) plus $950.00 an hour throughout the divorce which is the only thing that drags out longer than this film.

A few good moments from Laura Dern and Ray Liotta help overcome the tedium.

title: gets messy fast
review: Acted as a typical stageplay, driver and Johansson never touched me. The point why their characters want to divirce becomes more and more pointless. The lawyers are just cliches. better watch a woody allen movie from the 70s, he observed people much better.

title: Didn't quite get there. Seemed artificial and unsatisfying.
review:
I had heard such rave comments about this movie, I wanted it to be fantastic. (I don't watch many movies anymore, but this one attracted me by some of the reviews I read). Instead, I found the movie unsatisfying and somewhat boring, actually. I did not feel that the flame war between the divorcing couple (and between their attorneys!) was either compelling or realistic, more annoying and repetitive than anything else. The acting was competent, but a bit over the top for my taste.
The premise: couple still has affection for each other, but there's too much baggage, so they have to separate. They are both intelligent, so it's unbelievable that the wife wouldn't have communicated her dissatisfaction long before, and also that the husband would be so clueless as not to notice there were issues.
They are both overly consumed with getting custody of their son - it's their only important goal apparently. In the real world this could have been worked out as a joint custody agreement, regardless of where the parents chose to live. The first half of the movie seemed brilliant, then it dropped the ball. Nasty fight between the couple and between their attorneys. The guy caves in; gives up his career and moves to LA because his ex-wife wants it. She is an insufferable whiner. And a corny ending of their son finally learning to read at the age of 8 - what, he's a dyslexic? And what does he read? The blurb from the beginning of the movie where the wife wrote down all the things she loved about her "soon to be ex" husband. How cute? Not. A cheap and cheesy cop-out ending.

title: The copy of the Jodaeiye Nader az Simin (2011) film
review: This movie is copied from the movie Jodaeiye Nader az Simin (2011). That movie is much better and more conceptual than that.

title: Hollywood pap
review: Sick to the back teeth of Scarlet Johansen. Can't they find some new talent?

title: Not bad, certainly not excellent
review:
For those that have not gone through a divorce it is a challenge to connect or empathise with the characters. Personally I did not care for any of them.
The acting is good, and I get that those who once were in love and are now divorcing will say some horrible things, and lawyers will go for the jugular to leverage a result, but I found some scenes seemed forced such as the heated argument in Charlie's apartment. For example accusations resembling fathers and mothers came out of nowhere. There was nothing that set this up.
There's nothing particularly innovative about this film. The cinematography and editing is perfunctory, nothing special about the soundtrack, wardrobe set design etc but there are many nods to the stage for those looking for something a bit deeper.
MARRIAGE STORY was nominated for Best Film category and therefore I expected a lot more than was delivered.

title: Great acting for a self-indulgent movie
review: At times dull, others pretentious, often boring. Saved by the grace of a wonderful cast that is always overcompensating.

title: How is this movie rated so high?
review:
I don't understand the hype and high ratings. To give something 9 or 10 stars it has to be pretty remarkable in my opinion. This movie falls far short of that.

I found it to be too long and quite boring.

title: Unrealistic and unsatisfying.
review:
I had heard such rave comments about this movie, I wanted it to be fantastic. (I don't watch many movies anymore, but this one attracted me by some of the reviews I read). Instead, I found the movie unsatisfying and somewhat boring, actually. I did not feel that the flame war between the divorcing couple (and between their attorneys!) was either compelling or realistic, but was annoying and repetitive.. The acting was competent, but a bit over the top for my taste.
The premise: couple still has affection for each other, but there's too much baggage, so they have to separate. They are both intelligent, so it's unbelievable that the wife wouldn't have communicated her dissastisfaction long before, and also that the husband would be so clueless as not to notice there were issues.
They are both overly consumed with getting custody of their son - it's their only important goal apparently. In the real world this could have been worked out as a joint custody agreement, regardless of where the parents chose to live. The first half of the movie seemed brilliant, then it dropped the ball. Nasty fight between the couple, and between their attorneys. The guy caves in; gives up his career and moves to LA because his ex-wife wants it. She is an insufferable whiner. And a corny ending of their son finally learning to read at the age of 8 - what, he's a dyslexic? And what does he read? The blurb from the beginning of the movie where the wife wrote down all the things she loved about her "soon to be ex" husband. How cute? NOT. A cheap and cheesy cop-out ending.

title: It's okay, but forgettable
review: I watched this movie with my husband and the very high rating of ofcourse lead to high expectations. Unfortunately, the movie didn't live up to those expectations. Yes, the acting is great, but you don't really build a connection with any of the characters. Even though a lot of effort is put into the dialogues, it still feels like you never really get to know them, and therefore, you don't truly root for them. We watched it without any background information, so we were hoping on a marriage revival, but this never happens. You don't even see them make an effort to save it, despite the very touching letters they wrote about each others qualities in the beginning of the movie. For me, the movie was interesting while I believed there was still a chance of them making it better. That a deeper layer might be touched, instead of all the superficial lawyer stuff. (Which was amusing, and sometimes uncomfortable, but nothing more than that). However, it's all about the breakup and therefore, 'Divorce Story' would have been a better name. I cried while watching Mrs Doubtfire (also a dramatic comedy about a divorce, and a father doing anything to see his kids), but with this movie: not a single tear, not even close. The difference is: in Mrs Doubtfire, you could actually truly relate to the characters and their motives, their pain, you get attached to them as a family and as individuals. Marriage story didn't do that for us at all and I'm sure I've forgotten about this movie in 1 or 2 years. I'm still not sure what this movie wanted to teach us, if anything.

title: excellent performances
review:
An exceptional movie
He caught me from the first scene, with an excellent montage. best of all the performances, Scarlett Johansson makes you feel from the first to the last minute, showed us the versatility that.
Finally, a script that shows you the reality, without lies and with crusade as the situation described in the film.

title: Nice drama
review: I think I've never seen Scarlett Johanson crying so often like picture.

title: A masterpiece
review: Shocked to see so many 1 and 3 star reviews here, most of the so called critics here are complaining about Nicole's character that she's a selfish narcissistic woman who makes her ex husband's life miserable but they are missing a point here, marriage story is actually a tale about two flawed characters-Charlie who's a self absorbed man who cares only about himself and nicole, a woman who feels insecure and jealous of her husband's success, the critics here are critical of nicole but they don't realise that Charlie was a careless husband, he cared little of his wife's happiness, he hated his wife's home city for no apparent reason despite the fact that she loved to be there, he honestly didn't care about her, he didn't let her direct in his theatre company and was extremely controlling, slowly she starts loathing him but Charlie instead of correcting his mistakes fucks a woman who works with him, sure nicole had her own baggage but in no way she was responsible for all the problems in their marriage, her decision to stay in la with their child was correct, the child needed a family which only nicole could provide, the screenplay is brilliant and adam driver is terrific in this film, it's arguably the best film netflix has ever made

title: Great Script!
review:
It was a very unique and realistic setting for a family and one that is worth telling. I did not expect the amazing performance of Scarlett Johanson but she did incredible! An Oscar-worth performance. The feels were already there but I am not very convinced with the performance of Adam Driver. He did not fit the profile of Charlie but his acting has improved. Moreover, I did not expect anything that great when I saw the trailer because of their lack of charisma, but the excellent performance of Scarlett moved me, as if I totally forgot that she was Scarlett! Hahaha.

The story, though, really showed how disagreements are solved if lawyers are to be involved. It was almost depressing how the first part and the last part was perfectly connected, but it almost brought me to tears. It is a film worth watching alone if you want to get out of the real world and reflect with your own world.

title: Poor Charlie
review:
Loved the movie (direction, cinematography, acting this is why i give an 8) but don't kid yourself and think Nicole is just a good mother who wants best for her child.

I saw the movie with no side at first but it's clear as day that Nicole ruined him moneterally, emotionally. She even hacked the guy for god sakes

She wins everything she wanted (Career, Money, her son 24/7) and Charlie is in ruins... sad for the dude.

title: Yeah but I'm in it for the art..
review:
I went into my viewing of this film with the idea that it would be wonderfully acted, that was my one expectation having previously seen several scenes flash across my Instagram feed. The film was. Oh but that's not all...

First, there are so many stylistic choices that the director/writers made such as overlapping of voices in tense moments, tempo of action, and an overall mesmerizing choreography, (especially during a scene based around a film set) that make subconscious emotions flood into any viewers head. I loved it.

Second, framing by the cinematographer is excellent even when it breaks rules. In fact, especially when it breaks rules. There is a monologue that goes on for minutes, (feels like hours) where, as the dialogue progresses, the camera gets tighter and tighter on the subjects face. Not only does this highlight the emotion of the scene but draws the viewer in and makes them feel the "trapped" perspective of the helpless character. Another particularly beautiful idea was to stick 2 characters in the corner of a room and use the walls to guide the viewers perspective all the way into the corner. Normally this would be a no-no, especially because one of the characters bodies is turned to the camera, however again this illustrates the characters metaphorical position in life, he/she is being backed into a corner and their fate is unclear. Absolutely brilliant!

Here's why it's not a 10/10. A. I'm biased against sad movies, sorry I just am. B. There are several lines delivered by an otherwise Oscar-worthy performance by Adam Driver that feel like he didn't even try to deliver them. They fell so flat and ruined some scenes credibility. It made me remember I was watching a movie, (not good).

All in all it was a phenomenal experience and I feel like a better person after having viewed it, it puts a lot of things into perspective. This movie is centralized around divorce and I'm fortunate enough to not have had people close to me experience it (yet). Having said that it made me feel a ton of emotions and if it can do that for me, I'm sure it can for you!

title: Beautiful, hard hitting film! Driver Vs. Phoenix for Oscar
review:
I'll keep it short, but this film was something I'd read about before I'd seen it and I knew it would be good and it was better than I expected.

Scarlett Johansson and Adam Driver, despite playing out a love story that's already ended had such chemistry and played off each other with such grace. Their portrayal of parents who have so this much respect for each other and think they should hate each other and just don't, or can't. It's a tough thing to do, I felt like I was a watching a more entertaining update of Kramer Vs. Kramer. I loved every moment, but the pivotal argument scene that comes in quite late, which was bubbling under the surface for the whole film until it hits you in the face, Driver as Charlie seriously made me cry!

It's going to be a battle for Best Actor at the Oscars between Driver for this and Joaquin Phoenix for Joker. They both deserve to win.

Luckily being a Netflix film, I saw limited run at a cinema not far from home, like with The Irishman and The Two Popes, I did NOT watch them at home. So worth it.

And also my favourite for awards glory! I'll give Netflix this one.

title: Free writing
review:
Marriage Story(2019) by Noah Baumbach, who is often referred to as a younger version Woody Allen, would perhaps the most impressive and heart-melting film in this year. 1.66:1 aspect ratio, unique. What I love about the film is the screenwriter's well use of details, which really reminds me of the story about the condemned who avoided little puddles before being executed. Things like the haircutting, toilet flushing, lights turning, and door closing are not something easy for ordinary screenwriters to come up with.

Another thing I really like about it is the cinematography, especially the sense of film(35mm). I wonder what type of camera they use. After searching on IMDb (Arricam LT, Panavision Primo Lenses Arricam ST, Panavision Primo Lenses Arriflex 435, Panavision Primo Lense) I like the shallow depth of field that creates the deviation, the sense of distance of characters.



I like the shift of characters, especially the character arc of Charlie. Nicole ordering from the menu for Charlie, another powerful detail. I like the overlapped lines, such as others' comments on protagonists and the whispers on the court. One thing that's worth noticed is the monologue made by Nicole's lawyer. This could be a feminist expression(or discussion) made by the director. After they signed the contract, they both raised their heads. And it comes to the dissolved transition, which I always want to have in my videos.

Making mistakes while closing the closet, powerful a detail. Coming out of a subway and encountering the flyer sender who wants others to care about animals are nice details, well-designed echoing. Charlie singing Being Alive, a master-stroke. The son's dyslexia might be designed to serve the part of the letter reading at the end, also a brilliant echoing. I like the echoing of the beginning and end.

"Self-fish", "self-sufficient", a joke with complex feelings. Costumes of the Beatles definitely adds some flavour to this film.

I like the film's score, which contributes to the family's ambience. Mommy phase and Sgt. Pepper Shoelaces are my favourites for the downward marching of chords. Tying up shoelaces, a final master-stroke.

I always want my videos to include credit part like this(and The Darjeeling Limited). Netflix produced the two best films in 2019. (Another one is The Irishman by Martin Scorsese) Competetive nominee for Oscar best original screenplay and best acting.

title: It is emotional?
review:
It is emotional, well I'm not sure.
It's a story on how a divorce got out of hand even if at the beginning they have been reasonable persons.

title: Moved to tears
review: Noah Baumbach did it big time. Amazing dialogues and exceptional acting. Scarlet John is outstanding.

title: Depressingly Long
review: Although, there were some good parts/scenes. I found this flick be depressingly long. The characters were in my opinion exaggerated. But still worth a watch. I like Adam Driver, but not in this role.

title: It's all over but the shouting
review:
When Marriage Story begins, the marriage in question is already over. Here and there, in the beginning, the viewer might even question why they split up in the first place, or if they might get back together, but it becomes clear soon enough that, in the words of The Replacements' "Never Mind" ...it's all over but the shouting.

And so let's talk about the shouting. That instantly meme-worthy scene that took the internet by storm as soon as this puppy hit Netflix: wow. I mistakenly watched that and just that, and in comparison to the understated, well-edited trailers, it was an assault. It seemed as if there was no way the film could find itself there, or worse: was that, could that be the tonal emotional mean? Thankfully, it is not. At all. And, though that scene mostly doesn't work, it doesn't feel *so* out of place that the viewer is pulled out of the story. This is a film about tension, and the majority of that tension is unseen or implied. There's a lot of passive aggressiveness on display in place, and that felt real.

This is low 9 out of 10 in my opinion. I don't think it's Baumbach's best, but it's at least his best since 2013's Frances Ha. (Quick ranking of Baumbach: #1 Squid #2 Frances #3 Greenburg #4? Probably this)

title: Hard to watch when you can relate too much
review: I can not watch the film in one piece but have to come back to it three times to finally finish it. As a child and an adult I both experiences spliting families so to me this story is so real and beautiful told. At every moment I still want them back together with the knowing that they wouldn't, couldn't. Filmmakers did an awesome job showing it was a great love from the start of the marriage and still there in the end, but ending is ending and there's no way back.

title: A beautiful picture showing the hardships of human love an
review:
If you would read no further than this line: this is a beautiful film and you should see it.

Noah Baumbach has taken the same ingredients he used for his last film, The Meyerowitz Stories, and has balanced them with more skill, leading to a picture that shines on all fronts .

We observe the main characters, Charlie and Nicole, as they go through the motions of their divorce. We watch them struggle with their desires while they try to frame everything leading up to the separation - meanwhile going through all the emotions that bubble to the surface. They have a young child, Henry. Their relationship with him as they go through the break up is redefined, as the parents labor to keep their difficulties out of his world as much as possible. From the film's opening on you are invested in these people and that doesn't change until the end credits are rolling.

Adam Driver and Scarlet Johansson are just lovely. I mean, I don't know what else to say. These are two top of the line actors portraying well written characters in a heartfelt story. What's not to like? They make you feel deeply for Charlie and Nicole - their confusion, despair, frustration, doubt and hope, come across as believable and genuine. There will be moments in the film where you will feel their pain, and laugh at their silliness as they try to keep their heads above water.

The rest of the cast is a perfect fit, with Laura Dern, Alan Alda and Ray Liotta being particularly good as the divorce lawyers. I won't say too much about their characters or performances as not to spoil the film, but let's just say they represent that side of human nature we would rather avoid having to acknowledge.

Baumbach's unique writing style delivers a mix of clever, engaging and sometimes hilarious dialogue and a story that makes the character's feel very real and relatable.

This film is a great reminder that right and wrong, in their absolute fairytale forms, don't exist. People endeavor to love and often times they eventually fail. And while that's okay, the suffering that comes with it is inevitable. This picture does well in showing what that means on an existential front as wel as displaying the harsh pragmatical and logistical side of things that comes with a divorce when there's a kid in the picture, without giving us any easy, pre-made conclusions to hold on to.

title: Great female cast but so boring
review:
I really had an hard time finishimg this movie!
I found it boring and slow. Nothing new or a different point of view on telling about people splitting up.
I appreciated the actresses, especially Laura Dern and Scarlett.

title: marriage story
review: Marriage story is defienetly one of best films of this year and that is visiable in every scene through dialogue and hard theme to make in a todays times but baumbach suceeded in that and maded one of best divorce films maybe in history,all of that is leaded by strong,career best performances by scarlett and adam who sold every moment they were on screen together and even when they were seperate they remeinted strong,liotta and dern also did good job and they fitted very well in story and give story good impulse and dynamic,marriage story is one great film leaded by great direction and strong performances

title: I have no idea why but this movie is amazing!
review: Where do I start? I can't find a single flaw in this movie,, everything is absolutely great: The performances, the dialogues, the music, the characters and the way the director can make a movie that is just about a couple getting a divorce so damn interesting to watch. I really had very low expectations before going to see it because I was absolutely sure that I was going to be bored to death since there wasn't really any plot in it but I was dead wrong. Despite not having anything too exciting happening the movie is very pleasant to watch and I enjoyed every minute. Maybe it's due to the fact that it has a lot of dialogues and it doesn't feel slow or the brilliant performances of the protagonists. Either way I don't think that anyone is going to be disappointed after watching it. I totally recommend it!
